ABSTRACT Significant environmental issues have emerged from the increasing usage of fossil fuels, stimulating extensive interest in improving efficient energy production and storage systems. Electrocatalysis, which plays a crucial role in clean energy conversion, could foster the advancement of future sustainable technologies. Electrocatalytic activity is greatly enhanced by single-atom catalysts (SACs) because of their distinctive physical and chemical frameworks. The coordination environment can influence the geometry and electronic structure of SACs, contributing to the escalation of the efficiency of electrocatalytic for meeting practical needs. Due to their numerous micropores, greater surface area, and adjustable organic ligands, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been shown to be an excellent approach to developing SACs. This review provides a complete summary of current instances involving the synthesis of SACs originating from MOFs. In addition, this review also addresses the impact of single-atoms (SAs) on electrocatalytic activity within the local coordination environment, including the spatial distribution, coordination structure, and local electronic structure. Besides, the density functional theory that provides theoretical support for the electrocatalytic reaction has summarized and analyzed the application of SACs in the electrocatalytic field. Graphical Abstract Recent advances (synthesis, characterization, application, and mechanism) and perspectives of SACs originating from MOFs are summarized for improving the electrocatalysis of HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR. Keywords Electrocatalysis Metal-organic framework Single-atom catalyst Synthetic strategy Energy conversion reaction 1 Introduction The interaction between economic development, the diminishing availability of fossil fuels, and the escalating issue of environmental pollution [1–4] necessitates the expeditious exploration of sustainable, renewable, and ecologically sound approaches to ensure our future energy security [5–8]. This urgency is further compounded by the adverse effects of global warming, primarily propelled by carbon dioxide emissions and the inherent characteristics of existing fossil fuel sources [9–12]. The emergence of electrochemical energy preservation and conversion technologies has ushered in a very promising approach to mitigating our dependence on fossil fuels and addressing the environmental ramifications associated with such reliance [13–16]. This technology offers notable advantages, including its exceptional energy efficiency and limited ecological impact [17–20]. Electrochemical energy conversion can produce valuable chemicals from the earth’s abundant water [21–24], carbon dioxide [25–28], oxygen [29–32], and nitrogen [33–36] and store them (such as hydrogen [37–40], hydrocarbons [41–44], oxygenated compounds [45–48], and ammonia [49–52]. Improvements in high-performance electrocatalysts via scientific inquiry and development are seen as essential for boosting fuel cells, metal-air batteries, electrochemical water splitting, and other uses for electrochemical energy conversion. These electrocatalysts play a crucial role in facilitating the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [53–57], hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [58–62], CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) [63–67], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [68–72], and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [73,74]. Over the last several years, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have gained widespread use in electrocatalysis [75,76]. SACs exhibit high selectivity and can maximize the utilization of metal atoms, turning each atom into an active site, which greatly improves the rate and efficiency of the catalytic reaction and shows good stability due to its unique structure. This unique structure is increasingly favored by researchers and practitioners in the field [77]. The concept of the reaction active site was first proposed by H. S. Taylor in 1925 [78], and subsequently, single atoms began to play their role [79–83]. Notably, in 2011, SACs were initially conceptualized, emphasizing that dispersed metal atoms serve as the active centers in catalytic reactions [84]. As shown in Fig. 1 , these SACs were successfully prepared one after another [85–92]. Unlike conventional metal nanoparticle (NP) electrocatalysts, traditional electrocatalysts are prone to failure due to oxidation, reduction, and other reactions at high temperatures, high pressures, and other conditions. In contrast, SACs anchored on support materials have quantum size effects, unsaturated ligand structures, metal-support interactions, and a substantial increase in surface free energy, and so on, contribute to enhanced electron and mass transport, resulting in improved electrocatalytic activity, selectivity, and stability [93–96]. Specifically, (1) studies on SACs have shown that when the reaction active site of an electrocatalyst is reduced to the atomic level, the reaction active site can be maximized, causing a considerable improvement in the selectivity and efficiency of the electrocatalytic reaction [97–101]. (2) Strong interactions or charge transfer stabilize single-atom active sites on the supporting material, thus improving the atomic dispersion and the stability of SACs [102–106]. (3) The high surface energy minimizes the potential energy barrier for the catalytic reaction and helps to enhance the electrocatalytic reaction activity. In addition, due to the singularity of the bonding pattern of SACs, we can accurately predict their reaction active sites, making them ideal platforms for elucidating electrocatalytic reaction mechanisms [107–111]. Methods currently employed for preparing single-atom electrocatalysts with loaded single atoms include wet chemistry [112], atomic layer deposition [113], ball milling [114], and photochemical schemes [86]. However, these methods usually encounter a few problems, for example, many metal atoms that are typically suppressed and not well exposed to the catalytic reaction, low loading of single atoms (SAs), and poor dispersion on the support. Moreover, implementing these strategies is intricate and requires significant time, posing obstacles to their practical use. For a perfect SAC, the following conditions should be present: (1) SAs are distributed throughout the substrate in a consistent, homogeneous, and abundant manner, (2) the strong contact of isolated metal atoms with the support enables stable electrocatalytic properties even under high reaction loads and extended reaction times, (3) the provision of sufficient mass/electron transport channels to enable excellent electrical conductivity and stable electrocatalytic performance, and (4) exposure to good active sites. Just right, the metal SACs prepared based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as a model satisfy the above conditions [115]. MOFs are organic-inorganic hybrid materials with intramolecular pores formed by self-assembling organic ligands and metal ions through coordination bonds [116–120]. The precise organization of metallic nodes and organic ligands renders MOFs very suitable as a template for achieving homogeneous dispersion of single metal atoms [121,122]. MOFs have unique structures, such as morphological structures that can fully expose the active site, adjustable pores, ligand structures, etc. [121,123–125]. Consequently, MOFs are employed as templates for the synthesis of single-atom catalysts (SACs) and are commonly categorized based on their physical/chemical morphological structures and other properties: i) the metal nodes of the MOFs themselves are utilized as a single-atom source to prepare SACs [126], ii) MOFs with tunable pore properties can block/store metals and serve as single-atom sources to prepare SACs [127], and iii) MOFs with tunable organic ligands enable the synthesis of SACs by adjusting these ligands to immobilize single atoms [128]. Currently, some reviews have summarized the developments and processes of the SACs originating from MOFs for various electrocatalytic applications. However, previous reviews tended to focus on specific aspects or provided limited information regarding SACs originating from MOFs for diverse electrocatalytic applications. This review provides a concise summary of recent progress in the synthesis of SACs using various strategies that employ MOFs as precursor materials. The typical preparation methods and characterization techniques for SACs, along with their applications in electrocatalytic reactions (HER, OER, ORR, NRR, CO2RR), are thoroughly summarized and discussed. Finally, future directions are considered to facilitate the improvement of SACs as electrocatalysts for future practical applications and clean energy conversion. We hope this review and the references therein will inspire researchers to explore further and develop more advanced SACs. The application of SACs originating from MOFs in the field of electrocatalysis, as well as in other fields, will achieve more remarkable results. 2 Synthetic strategies for SACs from MOFs Due to the advantages of MOFs, such as tunable chemical composition, porosity, greater specific surface area, and unsaturated metal active sites, various MOFs can be prepared to derive SACs. The current preparation of SACs originating from MOFs usually employs in situ node evolution, encapsulation confinement, anchoring with ligands, etc. Currently, considerable progress has been made in preparing SACs using MOFs as precursors, in which many kinds of novel SACs. These methods have resulted in various novel SACs with uniform metal loading and highly loaded, easily accessible atomic sites exhibiting excellent electrocatalytic activity. This review provides a comprehensive overview of developments in SACs originating from MOF precursors. The main objective is to summarize the synthesis and characterization of different SACs originating from MOF precursors as well as the practical applications of SACs in diverse electrochemical reactions (Fig. 2 ). This section summarizes efficient methods for preparing SACs originating from MOF precursors. 2.1 In situ node evolution In general, it is an extremely common strategy to use the metal nodes of MOFs themselves as a source of SAs in the preparation of SACs from MOFs. The primary cause of this phenomenon may be ascribed to the conventional formation mechanism of MOFs, which entails the self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands [131,132]. This process is advantageous for achieving uniform dispersion and facilitating the construction of SACs during the synthesis procedure. For instance, ZIF-8, a representative member of MOFs, comprises 2-methylimidazole-bridged tetrahedral zinc ions and serves as a common precursor for preparing metal M-N4 active sites. Hou et al. [133] have effectively synthesized an electrocatalyst consisting of atomically distributed monovalent zinc species that are strongly bound to nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets. This electrocatalyst is referred to as Zn/NC NSs. The organic ligand is calcined to N-doped carbon through molten salt-assisted based on solid-phase pyrolysis. At the same time, Zn, the metal node in ZIF-8, is retained to form atomically dispersed monovalent Zn (Fig. 3(a) ) [133]. Wu and coworkers [134] also prepared Zn SAs electrocatalysts using ZIF-8 as a template. The pyrolysis of ZIF-8 was conducted at elevated temperatures in an inert gas environment, resulting in the partial reduction of Zn2+ ions in ZIF-8. This reduction led to the conversion of these ions into metallic zinc, which then vaporized at higher temperatures. The Zn2+ remaining after a certain process experienced further reduction, resulting in the formation of Zn+. This process ultimately resulted in the generation of atomically distributed Zn(I) sites. Subsequently, the Zn(I) sites were securely attached to nitrogen-doped porous hollow carbon nanofibers, yielding an electrocatalyst identified as Zn1N-C [134]. Additionally, Jiang et al. [129] conducted a study in which they produced an electrocatalyst of individual Ni atoms incorporated into a nitrogen-doped carbon (N-C) support material. This electrocatalyst was referred to as NiSA-N2-C. This was accomplished by employing a bimetallic precursor, namely a metal-organic framework (MOF-74) containing Mg and Ni metal nodes. Among them, Mg is used as a guest metal in MgNi-MOF-74, and the large amount of Mg2+ contributes to the spatial isolation of Ni2+ and prevents the aggregation of Ni2+, while the polypyrrole molecules were used as a nitrogen-containing guest to stabilize the Ni atom as an anchor point, and finally, the NiSA-N2-C electrocatalyst was prepared by pyrolysis (Fig. 3(b)) [129]. The metal Zn is similar to the metal Mg as a guest metal. Wu and coworkers [135] formed a nanocarbon-based Co single-atom electrocatalyst (20Co-NC-1100) by one-step pyrolysis of Co-doped ZIF nanocrystalline precursors and evaporation of the metal Zn during the process of pyrolysis. Besides, Mu and coworkers [136] prepared ZnCo-ZIF with Zn and Co metal nodes by a simple experimental method (ultrasound, stirring) and then subjected them to pyrolysis at 900 °C. During the process of pyrolysis, the evaporation of Zn atoms occurred, resulting in the immobilization of Co atoms on the nitrogen-doped carbon material. (Fig. 3(c)). Chen and coworkers [126] also prepared SACs that differ from most M-N-C structures by employing an Mn-based organic framework composed of Mn2+ and oxygen-containing trimeric acid linkers (1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (BTC)) as precursors. After calcination and acid (HCl) etching in an inert atmosphere, followed by activation with NH3, the final metal node of Mn was retained to prepare the Mn/C-NO electrocatalyst [126]. Atomically dispersed Co-N x nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube interconnected electrocatalysts (CoSA-N-CNTs) were obtained by pyrolysis (Ar/H2 atmosphere) and acid etching using ZIF-67 as a template [137]. The in situ node evolution strategy provides an effective method for preparing SACs by using the target metal as the metal node of MOFs. Following a straightforward single-step pyrolytic reduction process, the MOFs may undergo a successful conversion into structurally stable SACs. It is noteworthy that the combination of different organic ligands with metal ions forms MOFs. Similarly, SACs originating from MOFs have different metal SAs as well as different coordination environments around the metal SAs. Thus, it is necessary to find or develop suitable MOFs to prepare SACs to be applied to specific electrocatalytic reactions. These studies have deepened the understanding of using the metal nodes of MOFs themselves as SACs target metals for synthesis. 2.2 Encapsulation confinement Due to their abundant micropores, high surface area, and tunable pore size, MOFs have the property to adsorb and confine the guest material [138–140]. They can effectively prevent the shedding and aggregation of SAs and improve their selectivity. For example, Lou and coworkers [141] obtained iron-doped Co3O4 layered hollow nanoplates (named Fe-Co3O4 HHNPs) electrocatalysts by adsorption of guest metal salts on the inner and outer surfaces via solvothermal reaction using ZIF-67 as a template. The incorporation of guest metal salts into the reaction system is shown to induce an acid etching reaction, facilitating the conversion of ZIF-67 from nanoplates to hollow nanoplates characterized by distinctive cross-channels. Following the solvothermal reaction, the aforementioned hollow ZIF-67 nanoplates underwent a transformation process resulting in the formation of layered Co3O4 nanoplates that were constructed from ultrathin nanosheets. Due to composition and structural advantages, the Fe-Co3O4 HHNPs electrocatalyst exhibits good OER performance (Fig. 4(a) ) [141]. Also using MOFs as templates, N-doped carbon hollow nanorods (N-C HNRs) prepared from MOFs were utilized to trap Fe3+ in FeCl3·6H2O solution. Xu et al. [127] used a self-templated method in combination with a synchronous epitaxial growth procedure to construct ZIF-8 hollow nanorods with accessible surface defects. Afterward, these nanorods were subjected to pyrolysis, resulting in the disappearance of Zn elements and the generation of many N defects (NC HNRs). Subsequently, Fe3+ was adsorbed on the NC HNRs’ surface by impregnation. Finally, a unique Fe1-N-C HNRs electrocatalyst was fabricated by pyrolysis (Fig. 4(b)). Furthermore, Wang and coworkers [142] used ZIF-8 as a sacrificial template to produce Ni-N-C electrocatalyst. Specifically, during the synthesis of ZIF-8, Ni2+ is encapsulated in its flexible cavity and converted to Ni-N-C electrocatalyst in situ by one-step pyrolysis [142]. Notably, Pan and coworkers [143] showed from an atomic size perspective that a ZIF-8 cage having a 3.4 Å hole diameter and 11.6 Å cavity diameter could encapsulate nickel and cobalt atoms with a diameter of 2.5 Å in a ZIF-8 cage. Subsequently, Zn atoms were evaporated during the pyrolysis process, while Ni and Co formed Ni-N4 and Co-N4 sites, respectively, which were homogeneously implanted into the three-dimensional porous carbon substrate, and the Ni/Co diatomic electrocatalysts anchored on N-doped carbon substrates (NiCo DASs/N-C) were successfully synthesized (Fig. 4(c)) [143]. ZIF-8 was also used as a template for the preparation of Pt/Co double monatomic electrocatalysts since pyrolysis of Co-doped ZIF-8 produces porous carbon with higher surface defects that can be used for the adsorption of Pt precursors. Subsequent electrochemical reduction produced Pt1/Co1NC electrocatalysts with dispersed Pt and Co atoms [144]. In addition to using zeolite imidazole frameworks, other MOFs can serve as templates for preparing SACs. Xu and coworkers [145] prepared CoFe@MET-6 doped with Co and Fe ions using MET-6 as a template, followed by a one-step pyrolysis method in which the zinc nodes were reduced and volatilized. The decomposition of the organic ligands led to the generation of a significant quantity of gases, ultimately creating a hierarchical porous carbon network. Simultaneously, Co and Fe ions that were evenly distributed underwent a transformation, resulting in the formation of atomically scattered metal sites known as CoFe@C electrocatalyst [145]. In general, the encapsulation confinement strategy can successfully prevent the loss of metal atoms during high-temperature heating. This strategy is less restrictive on the species of SAs in the SACs, making it more favored. Nevertheless, when considering the high loadings of single metal atoms, it is important to acknowledge that the encapsulation confinement technique still carries the risk of aggregation occurring during the calcining process. 2.3 Anchoring with ligands The tunability of MOFs leads to the functional diversity of the materials, which acts like a kaleidoscope and offers many possibilities for engineering variations of MOFs to enable the design of SACs with high electrocatalytic activity [146,147]. For example, Liao and coworkers [130] prepared a Fe SAs electrocatalyst using ZIF-8 as the host material and ferrocene as the guest material. Specifically, ferrocene is placed upstream of the gas, while pre-prepared ZIF-8 is positioned downstream of the gas. As the temperature rises, the ferrocene is first vaporized and subsequently captured by ZIF-8. With increasing temperature, ferrocene and ZIF-8 were pyrolyzed and converted to C-FeZIF-4.44-950 electrocatalyst (Fig. 5(a) ) [130]. In addition to ferrocene, which can be used as a guest material for anchoring Fe SAs, iron phthalocyanine (FePc) can also be used as a guest material for anchoring Fe SAs to prepare Fe SACs. He et al. [128] used FePc molecules as the guest material and nitrogen-doped graphene nanomesh (NGM) generated from MOFs as the host material. The authors used K+/Li+ as a means of exfoliating and etching Zn-ZIF-L-derived carbon to fabricate NGM. Following that, FePc molecules were adsorbed onto NGM and then subjected to pyrolysis in an inert gas environment. This process yielded the SA-Fe-NGM electrocatalyst, which exhibited an exceptionally high metal concentration of 8.36 wt% (Fig. 5(b)) [128]. Notably, phthalocyanine is a programmable structural molecule. Bu and coworkers used ZIF-8 as a template, and the guest material was a programmable phthalocyanine dimer structural molecule (FeCo bimetallic phthalocyanine molecules) implanted in situ into ZIF-8. Subsequently, high-temperature annealing was performed to obtain adjacent Fe-Co dual-metal-atom implanted in an N-doped graphitic carbon electrocatalyst (FeCo-DACs/NC) (Fig. 5(c)) [148]. In addition, it should be noted that classical MOF-5 exhibits an ultra-high specific surface area and a profusion of porous structure, making it well-suited for the fabrication of a porous carbon support known as C-MOF-5. The C-MOF-5 support is later joined with a guest material, which is a complex Fe(II)-phenanthroline complex ([Fe(phen)3]2+), and finally pyrolyzed to obtain Fe SAC-MOF-5 [149]. Liu and coworkers [109] proposed a new idea to mix the porous carbon produced by pyrolysis of ZIF-8 as the starting material with melamine and metal salts in water with thorough stirring, and it is worth noting that the above powder can continue to stimulate the growth of carbon nanotubes under high-temperature in a pyrolysis process, and Co-900-A electrocatalysts can be obtained after acid washing. In addition to utilizing the exotic organic ligands mentioned above, it is also possible to anchor metal SAs by modulating the organic ligands of the MOFs themselves, such as Wang and coworkers prepared MOFs-derived N-doped carbon-loaded single W atom (W-SAC) electrocatalyst by altering the organic ligand of UiO-66 (replacing H2BDC with H2BDC-NH2) to prevent aggregation of metal atoms, encapsulating WCl5 in a UiO-66-NH2 framework, followed by pyrolysis (950 °C) and subsequent acid washing (HF). Notably, the organic ligand was replaced during the synthesis of UiO-66 to yield UiO-66-NH2, where the uncoordinated amino group played an essential role in inhibiting the aggregation of metal W atoms [150]. However, not all organic ligands are suitable for preparing SACs for electrocatalytic reactions. For different electrocatalytic reactions, a suitable organic ligand should be selected among a wide range of organic ligands. 2.4 Improvement strategies By reviewing, summarizing, and categorizing the above strategies for the preparation of SACs originating from MOFs, we have identified the unique advantages of using MOFs in the preparation of SACs (Table 1 ). However, it is essential to note that each SAC originating from the MOF strategy has certain drawbacks. For example, in the in situ node evolution strategies, one must consider that SACs originating from MOFs exhibit different single atoms (SAs) and distinct coordination environments around these SAs. Therefore, the search or development of suitable MOFs for the preparation of SACs applied to specific electrocatalytic reactions is labor-intensive. The encapsulation confinement strategy also has disadvantages that cannot be ignored. During the preparation of SACs, the encapsulation confinement strategy places fewer restrictions on the species of SAs in the SAC. Still, the encapsulation confinement strategy is prone to the risk of SAs aggregation when preparing highly loaded SACs. Hence, the encapsulation confinement strategy still has a long way to go in preparing highly loaded SACs. Similarly, anchoring with ligand strategies for preparing SACs has some drawbacks. Not all organic ligands are suitable for anchoring SAs to prepare SACs. Researchers must select suitable organic ligands from a wide range of organic ligands for different MOFs and SAs, making it another time-consuming and labor-intensive task. To address the aforementioned challenges, we can fully use the agglomeration phenomenon to combine nanoparticles with SAs, allowing nanoparticles and SAs to work synergistically. For example, FePc||CNTs||NiCo/CP electrocatalyst was obtained by combining single-atom (Fe-N5) active sites with nanoscale Ni-Co hydroxides via a carbon nanotube (CNT) bridging strategy. The obtained FePc||CNTs||NiCo/CP electrocatalysts benefit from this unique structure and exhibit excellent oxygen electrocatalytic properties superior to those of commercial noble metal Pt/C + Ir/C electrocatalysts. The high concentration of single-atom Fe-N5 active sites demonstrates good electrocatalytic ORR activity, while the nanoscale Ni-Co hydroxide displays robust OER activity (Fig. 6(a) ) [108]. At the same time, the charge density of the active metal sites can also be changed by introducing another metal single atom to change its adsorption energy to the reaction intermediates, which makes it an excellent bifunctional electrocatalyst with improved catalytic activity. Qiu and coworkers [151] synthesized CoFe-N-C by a two-step pyrolysis process and exhibited excellent electrocatalytic ORR and OER activities in alkaline media (Fig. 6(b)). This work reveals synergistic electronic interactions between Fe and Co bimetallic sites and a much higher electrocatalytic activity of the double-atom catalysts than that of SAC. Meanwhile, the formation of highly dispersed single atomic sites reduces the formation of nanoparticles and increases the number of reaction active sites, which can also improve the electrocatalytic activity of SACs. To achieve this effect, Yang and coworkers [152] designed a Zn-Fe-DABCO-TPA MOF that was immobilized on Ketjen black carbon as a conductive dispersion medium to form highly dispersed single atomic sites. The Fe/C950 electrocatalyst obtained by the above method formed a three-dimensional structure with highly dispersed metal atoms due to the introduction of dual-ligand, and the use of Ketjen black carbon further improved the dispersion of the metal atoms, resulting in higher ORR activity (Fig. 6(c)) [152]. Moreover, increasing the accessibility of the reaction active site also enhances the electrocatalytic activity of SACs. Guo and coworkers [153] prepared an electrocatalyst (Co SA@NCF/CNF) with carbon nanofibers as the main body and porous N-doped carbon nanosheets anchored by single metal atoms as the guest. The obtained Co SA@NCF/CNF electrocatalyst has a hierarchical porous freestanding structure, enabling higher active site accessibility and reducing the potential barrier for electrocatalytic ORR/OER, resulting in excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic activity (Fig. 6(d)) [153]. Through the above cases, we found that in addition to optimizing the synthesis conditions of MOFs and adjusting their morphology, structure, and composition to improve the electrocatalytic activity of SACs originating from MOFs, other methods can be used to enhance their performance. For example: (1) Metal ion exchange: During or after the preparation of MOFs, different metal ions can be introduced to change the electronic structure and chemical properties through ion exchange to optimize the catalytic performance of SACs. (2) Post-processing modification: The structure of SACs originating from MOFs can be further improved after post-treatment with heat and chemical treatments, etc. For example, some organic ligands can be removed by heat treatment to increase the specific surface area and reaction active sites of the electrocatalysts. (3) Construction of composite materials: Compositing MOFs with other materials (e.g., carbon nanotubes, graphene, etc.) enables the construction of composites with excellent properties. This strategy not only improves the loading and stability of SACs but also realizes the synergistic effect of multiple electrocatalytic functions. (4) Computational simulation assistance: Computational methods such as quantum computing and molecular dynamics simulation can provide insights into the electronic structure, reaction mechanism, and reaction active site information of SACs originating from MOFs. This can help guide experimental design and predict modification effects. (5) Green synthesis methods: Adopting environmentally friendly and sustainable synthesis methods to prepare SACs originating from MOFs can reduce production costs and minimize the environmental impact. For example, green synthesis methods such as hydrothermal and microwave methods are used instead of traditional high-temperature pyrolysis. In conclusion, the improvement strategies of SACs originating from MOFs are diverse, involving various aspects such as the optimization of synthesis conditions, MOF structure design, metal-ion exchange, post-processing modification, composite construction, computational simulation assistance, and green synthesis methods. The flexible application of these strategies helps to realize the efficient modification of SACs originating from MOFs to meet the needs of different electrocatalytic reactions and promote the development of related fields. 3 Characterization methods of SACs The characterization of SACs is of significant relevance for understanding their physical and chemical morphology. At the same time, the characterization of SACs is also decisive for preparing SACs and understanding the complex mechanisms involved in electrocatalytic reactions. Therefore, it is crucial to get a detailed explanation of the precise coordination environment and intricate structural characteristics of SACs. Currently, advanced analytical techniques exist that have been established to identify and understand SACs. These methodologies encompass aberration-corrected transmission electron microscopy (AC-TEM), extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (EXAFS), and X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) [9,154]. Simultaneously, a range of in situ characterization techniques have been established to capture transient reactions. These include in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (in situ FTIR), in situ Raman spectroscopy (in situ Raman), and in situ X-ray absorption fine structure (in situ XAFS) [155–158]. These methods enable real-time detection of changes in the chemical states of catalysts and intermediate changes of adsorbed molecules into catalytic products, among other phenomena. The combination of various advanced technologies provides valuable opportunities to design SACs with high catalytic activity for potential applications. In this section, we provide a concise overview of the in situ and non-in situ characterization methodologies discussed earlier. The aim is to enhance comprehension of the local coordination environment and microstructure of the SACs. 3.1 Aberration-corrected transmission electron microscopy The most straightforward method of visualizing SACs is by directly observing the dispersion of SACs on the support surface. AC-TEM is a commonly used technique for the examination of the atomic arrangement and structural characteristics of SACs [159–162]. The theory of Rutherford scattering elucidates a discernible difference in the luminosity between heavy and light atoms [163–166]. Currently, some important support materials, such as layered bimetallic hydroxides (LDHs) [18], 2D materials of graphene [85], MoS2 [167] and derivatives of MOFs [168], are often used to anchor SAs, and the distribution of SAs can be directly observed and analyzed in combination with AC-TEM. For example, Wu and coworkers used an in situ nodal evolution method to prepare a Co SAs electrocatalyst (20Co-NC-1100) with good electrocatalytic performance in ORR. The authors tested the 20CoNC-1100 electrocatalyst by aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC HAADF-STEM), which resulted in the discovery of uniformly dispersed isolated bright spots (Co SAs). Only C is found to be present when the electron beam hits the green circle. In contrast, upon shifting the electron beam towards the red circle, the electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) spectra reveal the detection of Co and N alongside the presence of C. This observation implies the potential existence of Co in the form of CoN x [135]. In addition to SAs in SACs, AC HAADF-STEM can also detect bimetallic atomic sites in SACs. Xu and coworkers [145] prepared a transition-metal-decorated carbon networks (TM@C, TM=Co, Fe or CoFe) electrocatalyst using the encapsulation confinement method with MET-6 as a template (Fig. 7(a) ). The CoFe@C electrocatalyst was tested using AC HAADF-STEM, which showed many mesopores (Fig. 7(b)). Scattered, isolated bright spots can be seen in Fig. 7(c), indicating the presence of Fe and Co SAs. Similarly, the SAs of Co and Fe can be identified in Figs. 7(d), (e) respectively [145]. AC HAADF-STEM has made an outstanding contribution to determining the existence of single metal atoms in SACs. Similarly, it serves other functions, such as observing the micromorphology of catalyst surfaces, interatomic distances, and so on. For instance, Wang and coworkers [169] prepare a Co SAs electrocatalyst (Co@DMOF) by decarboxylation-induced defect strategy by using mixed-ligand MOFs as precursors (Fig. 7(f)). To confirm the presence of Co SAs, the authors performed AC HAADF-STEM tests on the Co@DMOF-900 electrocatalyst, revealing abundant and isolated bright spot images on the carbon carriers in Fig. 7(g). EELS were able to check better the regular distribution of C, N, and Co atoms (Fig. 7(h)). Surprisingly, defects were identified while observing the Co@DMOF-900 electrocatalyst using AC LADDF-STEM analysis. In addition to the existence of non-hexagonal carbon defects within the Co@DMOF-900 electrocatalyst, flaws were also observed within the Co-N4 site Fig. 7(i). After DFT simulations, it was observed that the occurrence of a faulty structure near the Co-N4 site in the Co@DMOF-900 electrocatalyst has a notable impact on enhancing the intrinsic catalytic efficiency of the Co-N4 site. In contrast, the adsorption-free energy of *OOH on the Co-N4 site can be reduced, thus promoting the electrocatalytic ORR activity [169]. In addition, to investigate the impact of electron transfer zinc single atoms (Zn SAs) and cobalt single atoms (Co SAs) in DACs on the activity of ORR, Zheng et al. used a method of encapsulating cobalt(II) acetylacetonate (Co(acac)3) inside a hollow nanocage composed of ZIF-8), resulting in the formation of ZIF-8 @Co(acac)3. After successive pyrolysis, adsorption, and secondary pyrolysis processes, atomically dispersed ZnN4 and CoN4 sites were anchored to the nitrogen-doped doped carbon (ZnCo-NC-II) (Fig. 7(j)). The authors initially analyzed the HRTEM images and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) maps of the ZnCo-NC-II electrocatalyst, confirming the absence of metal nanoparticles and metal alloy phases (Fig. 7(k)). To further confirm the absence of metal particles and their alloy phases in the ZnCo-NC-II electrocatalyst, local HRTEM images were enlarged. However, no metal particles or metal alloy phases were observed. Instead, numerous lattice distortion defects were detected in the enlarged HRTEM images, which may be due to the coordination of the Zn/Co SAs and nitrogen (Fig. 7(l)). The characteristics of the ZnCo-NC-II electrocatalyst were observed and evaluated using AC HAADF-STEM. The results indicate that the Zn/Co atomic pairs exhibit a high degree of dispersion on the three-dimensional NC framework, as shown in Fig. 7(m). The inset of Fig. 7(m) displays distance statistics between the Zn and Co atoms, and the analysis shows that the average distance is 5.3 Å. Fig. 7(n) further indicates the distribution of the Zn/Co atomic pairs, which are flat horizontally (orange boxes) and up and down vertically (green boxes). Furthermore, DFT-based calculations demonstrate that the optimized ZnN4 and CoN4 sites are dispersed on the nitrogen-doped carbon frameworks at an atomic distance of 5.32 Å, which is consistent with the spaces between the ZnN4 and CoN4 sites observed by AC HAADF-STEM [170]. The AC-TEM and its accompanying devices offer extensive atomic-level analysis and ultra-high-resolution capabilities, enabling researchers to understand and observe matter at the atomic level. These tools are an essential pillar for matter analysis, creation, and application. Also, combined with XAFS and DFT, it provides a clearer understanding of the local coordination structure and the morphological structure of SACs. 3.2 X-ray absorption fine structure The use of the synchrotron radiation-based XAFS technology significantly contributes to understanding the local coordination structure of SACs [171–174]. Synchrotron radiation provides a detailed understanding of the coordination environment of an element (electronic structure, local atomic coordination structure, etc.) [175–178]. XAFS has two fundamental components: XANES and EXAFS [179–182]. XANES spectroscopy is used for the purpose of examining the geometric properties, electronic configuration, and oxidation status of the central atom inside catalysts [183–186]. The primary emphasis is placed on electronic transitions occurring within an energy range that extends from –20 to 50 eV. On the other hand, EXAFS analysis pertains to the examination of pertinent data about interatomic distances, bond lengths, coordination numbers, and radial distributions [187–190]. The system operates within an elevated energy spectrum, ranging between 50 and 1000 eV. As an example, Wang et al. [191] conducted XAFS tests to explore the local coordination environment of Mo species in Mo SACs anchored on nitrogen-doped carbon (Mo SACs/N-C). The Mo K-edge XANES spectra of many samples are provided by the authors, including Mo foil, MoC NCs/N-C, Mo SACs/N-C, MoC NPs/N-C, and MoC (Fig. 8(a) ). The energy associated with the absorption edge of the Mo SACs/N-C electrocatalyst is situated within the range bounded by the energy levels of Mo foil and MoC. This finding indicates that the mean oxidation state of molybdenum in the Mo SACs/N-C electrocatalyst falls within between the chemical valence states of molybdenum carbide and metallic molybdenum (Fig. 8(a) inset). The analysis of the XANES spectra, by the use of first derivatives, further confirmed that the Mo oxidation state in the Mo SACs/N-C electrocatalyst is between that of Mo foil and MoC. The curves obtained by k2 [χ(k)] weighted Fourier transform (FT) of the EXAFS data in R-space can be used to identify the coordination environment around Mo atoms in Mo SACs/N-C electrocatalyst (Fig. 8(b)). The curve obtained from the Mo SACs/N-C electrocatalyst displays notable disparities compared to the curves obtained from the Mo foil and MoC samples. It is worth mentioning that a prominent peak, which corresponds to the coordination of Mo-N/C, is observed at a distance of 1.4 Å. The use of the high-resolution wavelet transformation (WT) on the K and R spaces obtained from the Mo K-edge extended EXAFS curves offers a clearer representation of the coordination configuration of Mo atoms in Mo-N/C electrocatalyst. The findings indicate the absence of Mo-Mo coordination may be attributable to Mo-N/C coordination [191]. Moreover, Liu and coworkers [144] used XAFS to test and analyze Pt sites in a Pt1/Co1NC electrocatalyst to study their coordination environment. The determination of the density in unoccupied states for the 5d orbitals of Pt may be achieved by calculating the integral of the white line (WL) peak seen in the X-ray absorption spectra of Pt’s L3-edge. As a result, the researcher organized the valence states of Pt in increasing order, considering the intensity of the WL peaks as follows: Pt foil < Pt1/Co1NC < PtCl2 < PtCl4 < PtO2 (Fig. 8(c)). They performed a curve fit to the Pt L3-edge of the EXAFS, with peaks at 1.6 and 2.3 Å attributed to Pt-N/C. No metallic Pt bond was observed at 2.6 Å for the Pt1/Co1NC electrocatalyst, indicating the absence of Pt-metal bonds (Fig. 8(d)). The WT-treated EXAFS shows a WT intensity maximum of around 6.2 Å–1. This peak is related to the Pt-N/C (~1.6 Å–1) path of the Pt1/Co1NC electrocatalyst. This implies that the ligand atoms of Pt should be low-mass atoms [144]. XAFS has apparent advantages in studying the microstructure of electrocatalysts, and similarly, in situ XAFS is particularly beneficial for the surface and bulk phase microstructure of electrocatalysts under electrocatalytic reaction conditions, providing additional support for understanding the reaction mechanism [193]. For instance, to reveal the properties of Co reaction active sites in Co1/PCN electrocatalyst under electrocatalytic HER conditions, Wei and coworkers [192] performed in situ XAFS measurements. The use of XANES spectroscopy revealed a noticeable shift towards higher energy levels in the Co K-edge of the sample, transitioning from the ex situ sample to the open-circuit condition. This shift indicates a discernible elevation in the Co oxidation state. The fluctuation is more prominently seen in the disparity curve of the XANES spectra, as shown in Fig. 8(e). Furthermore, it is clear that the Co valence state in Co1/PCN exhibits a substantial rise when cathodic potentials of –0.04 and –0.1 V are applied, in comparison to the open-circuit voltage during the HER. This identification may be attributed to the fact that the absorbing edge is moved towards higher energies by around 0.6 eV. The Co K-edge XANES was analyzed to fit the average oxidation state. It can be concluded that the oxidation state of Co in the ex situ samples is close to +2.0 (~2.02), but the average valence state of Co in the Co1/PCN electrocatalyst rises to +2.20 and +2.40 at open-circuit and –0.04 V voltages, correspondingly. EXAFS spectroscopy enables the observation of the local environmental evolution of single Co sites. The FT k 3-weighted EXAFS spectra obtained at various applied potentials demonstrate a notable shift towards lower values of R for the Co-O/N peaks in the Co1/PCN electrocatalyst. Specifically, the shift is seen from 1.63 to 1.56 Å. The Co-O/N peaks in the Co1/PCN electrocatalyst are also observed in the low-R direction. The intensity of the FT peaks of the samples under open-circuit conditions and when the potential is applied decreases and then increases, suggesting changes in the coordination environments of the Co sites in the Co1/PCN electrocatalyst [192]. Another representative effort is Liu et al. [194], who conducted a study whereby they successfully produced a high-density Ni(I) single-atom electrocatalyst. This electrocatalyst effectively immobilizes Ni on nitrogen-doped graphene, resulting in an electrocatalyst that demonstrates both efficiency and durability in the process of electrocatalytic CO2RR. In situ XANES and EXAFS spectra of the Ni K-edge of the A-Ni-NG electrocatalyst in CO2-saturated and Ar-saturated KHCO3 solutions were compared. In a CO2 atmosphere, the K-line of Ni is transferred to a higher energy, about 0.4 eV, under an open-circuit voltage bias compared to Ar. The potential cause for the rise in the oxidation state of Ni might be attributed to the occurrence of a spontaneous transfer of charge from Ni(I) to the C 2p (CO2) orbital, resulting in the formation of CO2 δ– species. During the course of the reaction, it is seen that the Ni oxidation state of the A-Ni-NG electrocatalyst experiences a reduction (as shown by the K-edge shifting towards lower energy levels). This phenomenon suggests that the Ni oxidation state undergoes a cyclic transformation during the electrocatalytic process of CO2RR. The FT of the EXAFS spectrum reveals an augmentation in the amplitude of the principal peak at a distance of 1.45 Å, which may be attributed to the overlapping nature of the Ni–C bond with the Ni–N bond. At a potential of –0.7 V against the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), the elongation of the Ni–N bond, shown by a 0.04 Å displacement of the main peak towards the right, may be attributed to the distortion of Ni atoms located outside the graphene plane. At –0.7 V vs. RHE, the extension of the Ni–N bond (0.04 Å rightward shift of the main peak) compared to the open-circuit voltage bias is caused by the deformation of Ni atoms outside the graphene plane and the redistribution of Ni orbital electrons between the four N ligands and the Ni–C bond (CO2) [194]. Addition, Li et al. [88] conducted the synthesis of a range of Pt-Cu alloys containing embedded Ru atoms by acid etching and electrochemical leaching techniques. Among these electrocatalysts, the Ru1-Pt3Cu electrocatalyst has shown remarkable performance and stability in terms of electrocatalytic OER. To understand the electron transport direction of the Ru1-Pt3Cu electrocatalyst, Li and coworkers [88] performed in situ XAFS tests. With the potential going from 0 to 1.86 V, there is almost no change in the K-edge absorption threshold position and coordination of Ru1, representing that the oxidation state of Ru1 is stable (Fig. 8(f)). The observed stability of the Ru1 oxidation state in the electrocatalytic OER process is likely attributed to the charge compensation mechanism involving electron transfer from the Pt-Cu alloy to the Ru1 species. This transfer of electrons contributes to the overall stability of the system [88]. The achievement above demonstrates that in situ XAFS spectroscopy has the capability to examine the atomic-level electronic structure of the reaction site during electrocatalytic events. In conclusion, atomic-level exploration and analysis of the local coordination and electronic structure of SACs is possible using FT-, WT-EXFAS, and theoretical fitting, which is useful for learning about and advancing the utilization of SACs in the direction of electrocatalysis. 3.3 In situ FTIR/Raman In electrocatalytic reactions, besides the continuous effort to fully understand the electrocatalyst’s atomic structure and to study the structure of the catalyst in the working state, an in-depth study of the reaction intermediate is required. The detection and characterization of these transient intermediates are important for the mechanistic study of electrocatalytic reaction processes. However, structural changes in electrocatalysts and the very short lifetime of reaction intermediates are very difficult to detect. Therefore, this section describes two types of characterization applied to electrocatalytic reactions, i.e., in situ FTIR/Raman (for observation of reaction intermediates), which will be presented and highlight the important role of these analytical tools in elucidating the reaction mechanism [195,196]. 3.3.1 In situ FTIR In order to study the mechanism of the electrocatalytic reaction, the adsorption behavior of the electrocatalyst can be investigated by in situ FTIR spectroscopy, allowing for the direct measurement of the intermediates produced on the surface of the electrocatalyst. Fig. 9(a) shows the schematic diagram of the ATR-FTIR measurement. For example, Hou and coworkers used ZIF-8 as a template to prepare an atomically spread ZnI on nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets (Zn/NC NSs) electrocatalyst using an in situ nodal evolution method (Fig. 9(b)). The authors conducted in situ ATR-FTIR measurements on the Zn/NC NSs electrocatalyst to gain insight into the mechanism behind its impressive electrocatalytic CO2RR performance. At voltages between –0.5 and –1.2 V, the negative peak of adsorbed H2O at 1650 cm–1 is clearly visible. The adsorbed *COOH intermediate is the source of the positive signal at 1430 cm–1. The decisive step in the electrocatalytic CO2RR production of CO using Zn/NC NSs electrocatalyst is the protonation of *CO2 intermediates to form *COOH intermediates. As the applied potential increases, the Zn-N3+1 site located in the Zn/NC NSs electrocatalyst activates the H2O molecule and continuously consumes H2O to provide protons (Fig. 9(c)). Moreover, in contrast, the characteristic peak of H2O adsorbed by the bulk Zn/NC electrocatalyst is positive at 1650 cm–1. It can be seen that the *CO2 intermediates on the bulk Zn/NC electrocatalysts can be easily further protonated to form protons, whereas there are sites on the Zn/N3+1 electrocatalysts where H2O may bind to the *CO2 intermediates. The ZnN3+1 active site on the Zn/NC NSs electrocatalyst can effectively promote the dissociation of H2O molecules and the subsequent protonation process. After the depletion of H+ by the competitive reaction, a positive peak was observed at 1395 cm–1, which may be due to the retention of some *CO2 intermediates. The entire electrocatalytic CO2RR process was aided by the Zn/NC NSs electrocatalyst’s Zn-N3+1 site, which facilitated the fast production of the *COOH intermediate [133]. Moreover, to control the N species present in Fe-N-C catalysts precisely, Chen and coworkers devised a novel selective etching approach, hydrogen pyrolysis etching. In situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy was used to examine the connection between the structure and CO2RR activity of the H2-FeN4/C electrocatalyst. Mechanisms for the electrocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide using either H2-FeN4/C or N2-FeN4/C. It can be seen that the H2O peak of the H2-FeN4/C electrocatalyst is negative, while the H2O peak of the N2-FeN4/C electrocatalyst is positive in adsorption of CO2 and H2O vapors, which are 2343 and 1620 cm–1, respectively. It is fascinating to note that whereas the N2-FeN4/C electrocatalyst can only be spotted at –0.5 V, the H2-FeN4/C electrocatalyst has two peaks at –0.2 V. As a result of electron transfer from *CO2 adsorbed on the N2-FeN4/C electrocatalyst, *CO2 is reduced to *CO2–, which then combines with a proton donor (H2O) to produce a positive peak at 1620 cm–1. Surface *CO3H2 (1492 cm–1) is formed in huge quantities since the next protonation process only occurs at –0.5 V. No *CO3H2 was found because graphite N-activated H2O rapidly protonates *CO2– to produce *COOH on the H2-FeN4/C surface. With competing reactions on the H2-FeN4/C and N2-FeN4/C electrocatalysts leading to some H+ depletion, a small amount of CO3 2– was detected, while an increase in voltage led to a faster CO2 reduction reaction rate and a small amount of *COOH was detected (1430 cm–1). From the above results, it can be found that the co-adsorbed water on the atomic interface of “FeN4/graphitized N” atoms of the H2-FeN4/C electrocatalyst can promote the activation and protonation of CO2, which is beneficial to the electrocatalytic CO2RR [90]. The in situ FTIR spectroscopy is a dominant tool to obtain information on electrocatalyst surface reactants and intermediates, but some metal oxides have strong absorption in the low and mid-frequency in situ FTIR region, and the use of in situ FTIR spectroscopy can interfere with the characterization of active components. 3.3.2 In situ Raman In situ Raman can give many features of the electrocatalyst surface structure, such as the phase of active components, active sites, etc. In situ Raman spectroscopy, complementing in situ FTIR spectroscopy, has become a crucial characterization tool for studying electrocatalytic reaction mechanisms. Fig. 9(d) shows the schematic illustration of the in situ Raman measurement. For instance, Liu et al. [197] constructed a Ni SAC model with an accurate structure to prepare Ni-CNT-CC electrocatalyst by linking nickel (II) 2, 9, 16, 23-tetra(amino)phthalocyanine (Ni-TAPc) to CNT via C-C coupling. To determine the state change of nickel in Ni-CNT-CC electrocatalyst during electrocatalytic CO2RR, in situ Raman spectroscopic was performed. The two main Raman peaks of Ni-TAPc (isoindole deformation and Ni–N vibrations) are observed at 182 and 244 cm–1 (Fig. 9(e)). In the Ar atmosphere, when the potential reaches a certain level (above 0.57 V vs. RHE), Ni2+ starts to be reduced to Ni+, and the metal-nitrogen bond can be seen as weakened. When carbon dioxide (CO2) is used instead of argon (Ar), the vibrational peak of Ni-N is restored, both in terms of its form and position. This restoration stays consistent throughout a variety of cathode potentials, spanning from open circuit voltage to 0.37 V (vs. RHE). Comparable outcomes are achieved even at a potential of 0.37 V (vs. RHE) by substituting argon with CO2. The aforementioned findings suggest that the Ni present in NiTAPc undergoes reduction during the process of electrocatalytic CO2RR. Furthermore, the resulting Ni+ species exhibit favorable activity in terms of CO2 activation [197]. In addition, Sargent and coworkers prepared a Cu-FeSA electrocatalyst, assembling iron phthalocyanine (FePc) on the Cu surface and reducing it to iron SAC anchored on the Cu surface through an electrocatalytic process. This innovative approach was investigated using in situ Raman analysis, with pure copper as a standard, to explore both the synthesis of the Cu-FeSA electrocatalyst and the reaction intermediates in the electrocatalytic CO2RR process. The presence of copper oxides is suggested by the presence of a faint peak at 520 cm–1. Peaks at 365 and 1079 cm–1 are attributable to the Cu–CO stretch (*COCu) and the symmetric stretch of CO3 2– on the Cu surface, respectively, which occur as a result of the reduction of oxides on the pure Cu surface during CO2RR and the adsorption of the intermediate product CO, respectively. In contrast, the FePc phthalocyanine vibrations can be seen at 660, 745, and 935 cm–1 in the in situ Raman spectra of Cu-FePc, while the Fe–CO stretch peak can be seen at 535 cm–1 (*CO adsorbed on the Fe site) (Fig. 9(f)). Changes in potential (down to –1.1 vs. RHE and additional drops in potential) reduced the Raman peak of the phthalocyanine ring, indicating its detachment from the copper surface. Electrolysis results in the shattering of the Fe–N bond and the separation of the phthalocyanine ring from the central Fe ion, creating the Cu-FeSA electrocatalyst. At the same time, the Fe sites exhibit strong adsorption of *CO during electrocatalytic CO2RR [198]. These findings underscore the power of in situ Raman spectroscopy as a tool for obtaining insights into electrocatalyst surface reactants and reaction intermediates. This technique complements in situ FTIR spectroscopy, offering valuable information about specific structural features and characteristic molecules. The above-mentioned progress shows that the electrocatalytic reaction mechanism study has a decisive impact on experimental development. The changes in electrocatalysts during electrocatalytic reactions and the adsorption and analysis of transient intermediates generated by the reactions provide a research basis for exploring the creation of new electrocatalysts. In addition, an adequate reaction mechanism allows for a richer and more systematic study of electrocatalysis. The integration of empirical evidence and mechanistic investigations will be pivotal in developing sustainable advancement and transformative breakthroughs within the realm of electrocatalysis. However, existing techniques can only observe localized physical morphology or chemical mechanisms, e.g., AC-TEM can only observe the presence or absence of SAs in a small region of the electrocatalyst at a time, but not in a larger region or in the whole region, which makes us exhibit regionality in observing the SACs. There is a similar problem with synchrotron radiation because, during the experiment, we can only observe the chemical state and evolution of one element in a localized area. If we want to observe another element, we have to carry out the next experiment, which will inevitably affect the timeliness and efficiency of the experiment. The complementary nature of in situ FTIR/Raman provides significant assistance in studying the mechanisms of electrocatalytic reactions. Nevertheless, it is also due to the complementary nature of in situ FTIR/Raman in detecting the electrocatalytic reaction mechanism of electrocatalysts that some information unobservable to the researcher is inevitably lost in this complementarity, which may lead to biased electrocatalytic reaction mechanism studies. Another inevitable problem is that the cost of using these advanced characterization techniques may be prohibitive to the average research team, slowing down the pace of research. In response to the above problems, it is not impossible to develop advanced characterization techniques to solve the corresponding problems in today’s rapidly changing technology. 4 Theoretical prediction for SACs In addition to the physical/chemical structure of SACs, DFT calculations can play a crucial role as an effective technical tool to help us study catalyst properties and mechanisms of reaction at the atomic level [199–202]. It is worth noting that DFT calculations can also be used to determine the most stable and favorable single-atom configuration for electrocatalytic reactions on the support [203–206]. In conjunction with DFT computations, comprehensive insights into the molecular structure, charge distribution, energy band structure, and adsorption capacity of SACs may be acquired. This enables a meticulous atomic-level analysis of SACs. The charge density difference is a crucial tool in the exploration of electronic structure. It enables the visualization of electron flow following the interaction of distinct fragments, as well as the examination of changes in electron density during the formation of molecules from atoms [207–211]. Additionally, it facilitates the study of the characteristics of chemical bonding [210,212–215]. Furthermore, the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) can help us to determine the direction in which the reaction proceeds and the energy barrier that the reaction needs to cross, etc., to help us understand the mechanism of electrocatalytic reactions [216–220]. Meanwhile, the projected density of states (PDOS) plays a vital role in investigating the energy band structure and electronic characteristics of SACs. By using PDOS, researchers may get insights into the electronic structure of SACs and unravel the underlying reaction mechanisms involved in their electrocatalytic processes [221–225]. For instance, Li and coworkers [226] used an amino-functionalized ZIF-67 to create an N-doped porous carbon framework (NDPCF) that they then used to encase PtSA and CoPt-alloy nanocrystals. In both basic and acidic solutions, the obtained electrocatalyst, comprised of single-atom Pt and Co-Pt alloy nanocrystals enclosed inside an NDPCF (CoPt-PtSA/NDPCF), showed outstanding electrocatalytic HER performance. Li and coworkers used DFT calculations to determine why the CoPt-PtSA/NDPCF electrocatalyst exhibits high HER activity in 1 M KOH solutions. The use of computational models for the analysis of the experimental electrocatalyst revealed that the reduction in the number of N coordination sites from six to two or one resulted in the heightened activity of all Co sites within the cluster and the distinct PtSA sites of the Co6-N1N2 electrocatalyst for the electrocatalytic HER. The experimental resulting electrocatalyst was found to be constituted of nanocrystals of CoPt alloy and PtSA. Therefore, the authors evaluated three electrocatalysts, Co5Pt-PtSA-1, Co5Pt-PtSA-2, and Co5Pt-PtSA-3, each containing Pt atoms at a different location. Several distinct locations of the Pt atom in the Co5Pt-PtSA-2 (Co5Pt alloy and PtSA coordinated with one or two N atoms) alloy demonstrate |ΔG H*| close to zero (0.007–0.012 eV), making it an ideal HER electrocatalyst. Thus, the Co5Pt-PtSA-2 electrocatalyst was further investigated (Fig. 10(a) ). As can be seen from the charge density difference, when Co5Pt alloys or PtSA are coordinated with two N atoms, the charge transfer between them and the nearby atoms is much less. When metal (Pt or Co) atoms are coupled to one or two N atoms, their ΔG values decrease that act as HER active sites in the Co5Pt-PtSA-2-N2 and Co5Pt-PtSA-2-N1 electrocatalysts are |ΔG H*| = 0.059–0.107 eV, |ΔG H*| = 0.019–0.233 eV, respectively. These results illustrate why the HER activity of the synthesized CoPt-PtSA/NDPCF electrocatalyst is outstanding. In order to understand the mechanism of HER activity for various electrocatalysts, it is typically possible to utilize the d-bands computed from the d-band centers of the PDOS to estimate the adsorption capacity of the electrocatalyst. Co5Pt-PtSA-2 has more HER activity than other electrocatalysts because its d-band occupancy is higher at the Fermi level, allowing more free electrons to speed up the H* conversion rate. An enhancement in the d-band center value decreases the ΔG H* value at the Pt site, thereby controlling HER activity at the Pt site of the electrocatalyst (Fig. 10(b)) [226]. At the same time, in order to further understand the role of OER activity and atomic steps in ruthenium-iridium (RuIr) nanocrystals homogeneously dispersed on MOFs-derived carbon support (RuIr@CoNC) electrocatalyst, Liu and coworkers developed a model based on flat and step surfaces by observational experiments and performed DFT calculations. The reaction path of OER over the Ru0.5Ir0.5O2 (120) surface (step) electrocatalyst is shown in Fig. 10(c). The diagrammatic ΔG shown in Fig. 10(d) illustrates that the rate-determining step (RDS) for the OER on both flat and step completely oxidized (Ru0.5Ir0.5O2) surfaces is the conversion of O* to OOH*. Overpotentials of up to 2.029 and 1.884 eV occur in the flat and step partial oxidations, and for the fully oxidized Ru0.5Ir0.5O2, the predicted RDS to OER overpotential has significantly been reduced to 0.515 eV for the step surface and 0.578 eV for the flat surface, which is consistent with the experimental results that the presence of atomic bench levels reduces the RDS overpotential and promotes OER. The PDOS for the planar and step surfaces, and it can be noted that the center of the d-band of the step surface (–1.61 eV) is shifted downward relative to the planar surface (–1.28 eV), which may lead to weaker adsorption of oxygen intermediates. In the context of Bader charge analysis, it is evident that metal atoms positioned along the step surface exhibit elevated charge magnitudes when contrasted with their counterparts on the flat surface. The discrepancy in charge magnitudes might lead to a decrease in the chemical intermediates’ binding affinity strength. This is attributed to the lowered oxygen coordination (O1) in the atomic steps. The findings above indicate that the Ru0.5Ir0.5O2 (step) electrocatalyst can reduce the adsorption capacity of oxygen intermediates. This observation aligns with the free energy diagram, enhancing the electrocatalytic OER activity [227]. In addition, Li and coworkers successfully prepared N-coordination structures (ZnN4) (Fig. 10(e)) or O- and C-coordination structures (ZnO3C) (Fig. 10(f)) electrocatalyst by changing the functional groups of MOFs precursors and rationalizing the coordination environment of Zn single atoms. To determine the influence of the Zn coordination structure on the ORR pathway, the authors optimized the geometrical model of single-atom Zn in different coordination environments by DFT calculations. The electron dispersion around Zn in the ZnO3C and ZnN4 electrocatalyst models was studied by differential charge density. O is more electronegative than N. O traps more electrons from Zn, resulting in the accumulation of more electrons around O (Fig. 10(g)). The ZnO3C electrocatalyst exhibits a lower d-band center compared to the ZnN4 electrocatalyst, resulting in a decreased adsorption affinity between the oxygen-containing intermediate and the active metal site. Consequently, this facilitates the generation of H2O2. The authors performed ΔG calculations for the 2e–/4e– ORR reaction paths of ZnO3C and ZnN4 electrocatalysts at 0 V. For the ZnO3C electrocatalyst, ΔG *OOH is 4.24 eV, which indicates that OOH* on the ZnO3C electrocatalyst preferentially undergoes hydrogenation reactions to produce H2O2 rather than dissociation to produce H2O. Meanwhile, the ZnN4 electrocatalyst, with a ΔG *OOH of 3.83 eV, proved its preferential tendency to produce H2O. The dissociation of OOH* to O* is inhibited because of the reduced adsorption strength of the ZnO3C electrocatalyst on OOH*, which contributes to its better performance in the 2e– ORR [101]. Furthermore, Voiry et al. [228] used a salt template approach to synthesize an ultrathin, two-dimensional N-doped carbon-based single-atom Ni-loaded electrocatalyst (referred to as SA Ni-NC). This electrocatalyst exhibited remarkable selectivity and efficiency in converting CO2 to CO. The authors first performed DFT calculations to determine a model CO2RR electrocatalyst. Fig. 10(h) illustrates the reaction pathway involved in the reduction of CO2 to CO using SA Ni-NC electrocatalyst. Two proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) processes are involved in the pathway, and they are associated with forming *COOH and *CO intermediates. The ΔG of the *COOH intermediate formed by the NiN4 electrocatalyst is 1.55 eV, corresponding to the RDS of electrocatalytic CO2RR at a single atomic site. The RDS in Ni (111) electrocatalyst is the desorption of *CO from Ni (111) with an associated ΔG change of 1.65 eV. The change in ΔG of the RDS for the NiN4 electrocatalyst exhibits a reduction as the applied voltage increases. Under the same conditions, the RDS for the Ni (111) electrocatalyst exhibits a relatively consistent behavior. In order to get a deeper comprehension of the CO binding characteristics on NiN4 and Ni (111) electrocatalysts, the PDOS was computed both in the presence and absence of CO. The Ni (111) electrocatalyst exhibited high chemisorption for CO molecules. However, the spontaneous desorption of CO over the NiN4 electrocatalyst (Fig. 10(i)). Based on the investigation mentioned above, it can be inferred that the expeditious desorption of CO on the NiN4 electrocatalyst significantly influences the selectivity of the electrocatalytic CO2RR toward the production of CO [228]. Currently, theoretical calculations, especially quantum chemical calculations based on density general function theory, have become a powerful tool for academic theoretical research. It solves many problems in atoms and molecules, such as the order of charge transfer in electrocatalysts, the rate constants for adsorption/dissociation, reduction/oxidation, and binding/release of species at surface locations [229–234]. Gain insight into the atomic details of relevant transfer and reaction processes that are difficult or impossible to resolve experimentally. Therefore, the theoretical calculation of the reaction system can provide a theoretical basis for determining the physical/chemical structure of SACs and the reaction mechanism of SACs in electrocatalytic reactions. Although many current studies have performed theoretical calculations and solved many problems, natural systems are much more complex than those modeled by theoretical calculations. For example, charge density difference can only be calculated to model the flow of electrons in a given region and the change in electron density during the formation of molecules from atoms, among other things. We need to develop a simulation system that is more comprehensive and closer to reality. It enables researchers to demonstrate the electrocatalyst’s actual change process and the electrocatalytic reaction’s transition state in a simulation system that mimics real-time changes in these situations. This will significantly facilitate the preparation of electrocatalysts and the study of electrocatalytic reaction mechanisms, thus accelerating the application of SACs originating from MOFs from laboratory to industrialization. 5 Electrocatalytic applications SACs possess promising attributes for numerous electrochemical energy conversion applications owing to their atomically dispersed active sites and exceptional efficiency in utilizing single atoms. By tuning the coordination environment of single atoms, SACs can exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activity, selectivity, and stability in various electrocatalytic reactions (HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, NRR). This section will summarize recent developments in using SACs in these electrochemical processes. This discussion aims to dive into the many categorizations of SACs, explain the unique features of their active site designs, and analyze the effects these factors have on electrocatalytic performance and selectivity. 5.1 SACs originating from MOFs for the HER Alternatives to traditional fossil fuels are being explored [235–238], and hydrogen energy has been recognized as a feasible and sustainable approach [239–243] owing to its notable attributes of high energy density and ecologically benign characteristics [244–247]. Therefore, it is widely considered the most viable contender for the next age of eco-conscious energy alternatives [248–252]. Hydrogen energy production using electrochemical water–splitting technology can achieve zero carbon emissions [253–256]. However, it is crucial to develop electrocatalysts through less overpotential and high efficiency for industrialization [257–260]. SACs with ultra-high atomic utilization can lead to abundant active sites, which is advantageous for electrocatalytic HER. Among the many synthetic methods, using MOFs as precursors to prepare SACs is one of the most effective methods. Researchers have successfully used a combination of Ru and Co to get good results in the electrocatalytic HER application, owing to the observed synergistic impact between these two elements. Mu et al. synthesized N-doped carbon-based Co single atoms (Co-SAs/N-C) using a pre-designed bimetallic ZnCo-ZIF pyrolysis technique. The resulting material was then subjected to chemical reduction of the metal salts to create metal clusters in the presence of the Co-SAs/N-C electrocatalyst. Due to the synergistic interaction between Ru clusters and Co single atoms, the Ru/Co-SAs/N-C electrocatalyst exhibits excellent HER activity. This electrocatalyst demonstrated excellent electrocatalytic performance and long-lasting stability under various pH conditions, particularly excelling in a 1 mol L–1 KOH solution. Notably, the electrocatalyst exhibited a substantially lower overpotential of merely 7 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm–2, surpassing the performance of the Pt/C electrocatalyst, which had an overpotential of 40 mV [136]. There is another example of this in the work of Liu and coworkers [263], who used a simple carbonization and galvanic replacement strategy to design an electrocatalyst with Ru atoms dispersed on Co nanoparticles and confined within a microporous N-doped carbon matrix. The electrocatalysts known as M-Co NPs/Ru SAs/NC showed effective HER activity in alkaline electrolytes. The M-Co NPs/Ru SAs/NC electrocatalyst demonstrates remarkable efficiency, as evidenced by its ability to achieve a low overpotential of 34 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm–2, denoted as η 10 = 34 mV. Additionally, it exhibits a significantly high turnover frequency (TOF) of approximately 4284 H2 h–1 at a potential of –0.05 V. Notably, this TOF value surpasses that of the Pt/C electrocatalyst. It is noteworthy to emphasize that, the mass activity of the M-Co NPs/Ru SAs/NC electrocatalyst is about 2280 A g–1 at –0.05 V, which is approximately 21 times greater than that of the Pt/C electrocatalyst, which is approximately 107 A g–1. The superior HER activity can be achieved by enhancing charge transfer and manipulating electronic states through dynamic Co-Ru bond contraction with robust electron coupling effects. This can be accomplished by constructing atomically distributed Ru SACs on Co nanoparticles in a microporous N-doped carbon. The adsorption of water molecules is significantly promoted, leading to accelerated dissociation and improved HER performance [263]. There is also a strong synergy between the alloy and SAs compared to NPs. Li et al. [226] conducted the synthesis of an electrocatalyst denoted as CoPt-PtSA/NDPCF, which involves the incorporation of PtSA and CoPt alloy nanocrystals into an N-doped porous carbon framework (NDPCF) generated from amino-functionalized ZIF-67. Under alkaline electrolyte, CoPt-PtSA/NDPCF electrocatalyst exhibited lower overpotential (η 10 = 31 mV) and smaller Tafel slope. In addition, the TOF per Pt atomic site in the CoPt-PtSA/NDPCF electrocatalyst (TOF = 18.59 H2 s–1) was 32.05 times greater than that of the 10% Pt/C electrocatalyst and better stability than Pt/C electrocatalyst. It is possible that the ability of CoPt-Pt SACs to achieve such impressive results may be due to the close collaboration between the Pt SACs and the CoPt-alloy nanocrystals encased in NDPCF. This result, with an extremely low |ΔG H*| value of around 0.059 eV, is crucial for augmenting the electrocatalytic HER activity [226]. Meanwhile, the dual active sites significantly enhanced the electrocatalytic HER activity. Liu and coworkers first prepared Co1NC with abundant defects using ZIF-8 as a template for the adsorption of Pt precursors and then performed electrochemical reduction at room temperature to obtain Pt1/Co1NC electrocatalyst in which Pt and Co atoms were dispersed (Fig. 11(a) ). In 0.5 mol L–1 H2SO4, the Pt1/Co1NC electrocatalyst, featuring two individual atoms, demonstrated remarkable electrocatalytic performance for the HER. It achieved a current density of 10 mA cm–2 with a minimal overpotential of 4.15 mV. Moreover, when an overpotential of 20 mV was applied, the mass activity measured a high value of 32.4 mg–1 Pt. (Fig. 11(b)). The TOF value of Pt1/Co1NC electrocatalyst was 32.86 s–1 at an overpotential of 20 mV, which exceeded that of most noble metal-based HER electrocatalysts, as well as good stability. In the Pt1/Co1NC electrocatalyst, the presence of N/C defects plays a crucial role in anchoring and forming monodisperse Pt and preventing metal aggregation [144]. Furthermore, Xiong and coworkers [261] prepared a composite catalyst with three-dimensional sponge-like structures (SGNCs) assembled from graphene nanocages (carbon-encapsulated Ni NPs and Ni SAs supported by immobilized N-doped graphene nanocage substrates) using nickel-based MOFs as a template. The process of simultaneous atomization and aggregation at elevated temperatures resulted in the formation of twofold active sites consisting of both nanoparticles and single atoms on the graphene nanocages (Fig. 11(c)). The use of the developed SGNCs-900 electrocatalyst resulted in the manifestation of exceptional HER performance, specifically at a current density of 10 mA cm–2, which corresponds to an overpotential of 27 mV. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the Tafel slope of the SGNCs-900 electrocatalyst (38 mV dec–1) is much lower related to other SGNCs electrocatalysts, as seen in Fig. 11(d) [261]. In another example, Fan and coworkers prepared an A-Ni-C electrocatalyst by calcination, acid washing, and electrochemical activation using Ni-MOFs as the precursor using an in situ nodal evolution approach (Fig. 11(e)). The electrocatalyst A-Ni-C displayed an overpotential of 34 mV when operating at a current density of 10 mA cm–2, as depicted in Fig. 11(f). Furthermore, at a higher current density of 100 mA cm–2, it exhibited an overpotential of 112 mV. Additionally, its Tafel slope value was determined to be 41 mV dec–1. Due to the strong chemical and electronic coupling between the graphitized carbon and Ni SAs, the A-Ni-C electrocatalyst allows effective electrical communication between the electrocatalytic active site and the underlying electrode matrix, which leads to a good electrocatalytic HER performance (Fig. 11(g)) [262]. Unlike the above methods, the electrocatalytic HER efficiency of SACs significantly improved by varying the coordination surroundings of SAs. Wang and coworkers [150] used anchoring with ligands to anchor W atoms to N-doped carbon derived from aminated UiO-66 to obtain W-SAC electrocatalyst. Emphasizing the crucial role of the uncoordinated amine group within UiO-66-NH2, it plays a significant part in reducing the aggregation of W atoms. This led to the creation of a remarkable electrocatalyst known as W-SAC, which displayed outstanding electrochemical activity when applied to the HER in alkaline conditions. Notably, it exhibited a mere 85 mV overpotential (η 10) and a low Tafel slope of 53 mV dec–1, making its activity comparable to the Pt/C electrocatalyst. Furthermore, the W-SAC electrocatalyst displayed high activity and stability in alkaline and acidic electrolytes. The electrocatalytic performance of the W-SAC electrocatalysts was found to be much superior to that of the WC and WN electrocatalysts. This notable improvement may be ascribed to the distinctive structure of the W1N1C3 molecule, which is likely the most reactive site in the electrocatalytic HER process [150]. Furthermore, Wang et al. [89] introduced a novel synthetic approach for incorporating triphenylphosphine into MOFs to enable in situ phosphorylation and the subsequent creation of Co1-P1N3 interfacial structures. This material represented as Co-SA/P-in situ and demonstrated unexpected electrocatalytic HER activity and permanence in an acidic environment. It achieved a Tafel slope of 47 mV dec–1 and an overpotential of 98 mV at 10 mA cm–2, surpassing the performance of the electrocatalyst with Co1-N4 interfacial structure [89]. In addition, many researchers have prepared a variety of SACs using MOFs as a template, and all of them showed good electrocatalytic HER performance (Fig. 12 ) [89,109,123,136, 143,144,150,226,261–267]. In conclusion, we report the application of SACs originating from MOFs in electrocatalytic HER. SACs have been found to be a viable technique to significantly speed up the reaction kinetics of HER due to their distinct physical and chemical structure. Compared with other materials, SACs exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activity in electrocatalytic HER but have not yet made outstanding contributions under large current density, which may be attributed to the fact that electrocatalytic HER under large current density leads to relatively large currents passing through SAC, which leads to redox reactions in SAC, resulting in the aggregation or detachment of SAs, and thus affects the stability of SAC in the high-current state. The amount of SAs loading on the SACs may also be responsible. Therefore, researchers need to make efforts to adjust the coordination structure of SAs in SACs so that they can both increase the loading of SAs on the SACs carrier to improve the performance of electrocatalytic HER and improve the stability of their SACs, for example, through the formation of coordination bonds between the metal SAs and electronegative atoms with greater electronegativities (N, O, P etc.), so that the metal SAs will be in a high valence state. 5.2 SACs originating from MOFs for the OER In light of the ongoing alteration of the global energy system [268–272], the need arises to foster the development of environmentally friendly and sustainable energy alternatives as viable substitutes for conventional fossil fuel resources [273–277]. Electrocatalytic OER is important in the context of electrochemical metal-air batteries [278–282] and overall water splitting [283–287] since it serves as a crucial half-reaction [288–292]. The use of MOFs as precursors allows the synthesis of SACs with spatially restricted effects and tunable pore size, which can maximize the exposure of catalytic reaction active sites and promote electrocatalytic OER. For example, Qiao and coworkers [293] used ZIF-67 as a template. Subsequently, they assigned Ir to ZIF-67 by ion exchange to obtain Ir@ZIF-67 and later obtained Ir0.06Co2.94O4 electrocatalyst by pyrolysis according to the in situ node evolution method (Fig. 13(a) ).
