Fig. 13(b) illustrates the remarkable electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalyst in the OER application within a 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 electrolyte, where it displayed an onset potential (E onset) of 1.45 V. Specifically, at an overpotential of 1.53 V (vs. RHE), the electrocatalyst Ir0.06Co2.94O4 demonstrated exceptional efficiency in terms of both OER current density, measuring 5.99 mA cmox –2, and mass activity, which was measured at 2511 A gIr –1. This value was notably higher than the parent oxide (Co3O4), surpassing it by two orders of magnitude (Fig. 13(c)). Enhancements in the electrocatalytic performance and resistance to corrosion of the electrocatalyst in acidic environments can be attributed to alterations in its electronic configuration. These alterations encompass a downward displacement of the Co d-band center, the creation of a band gap within the Ir-5d band, and the expansion of the valence band. Collectively, these modifications contribute to the heightened durability of the electrocatalyst [293]. The energy band structure can be altered by ion exchange to improve the proficiency of electrocatalytic OER. In addition, optimizing the crystal surface is also effective in increasing the number of reactive active sites in the catalytic process. Liu and coworkers [227] prepared cobalt-nitrogen-carbon (CoNC) using ZIF-67 as a template and subsequently prepared RuIr nanocrystals uniformly dispersed on MOF-derived carbon support (RuIr@CoNC) electrocatalyst using an encapsulation confinement method. The synthesized RuIr@CoNC electrocatalyst exhibited excellent electrocatalytic OER performance (η 10 = 223 mV) and exhibited a high-mass activity of 2041 A gRuIr –1 at an overpotential of 300 mV in a 0.5 mol L–1 H2SO4 electrolyte. The superior performance of the RuIr@CoNC electrocatalyst can be attributed to two main factors. The abundance of atomic steps on the surface serves to increase the accessibility of highly reactive sites, leading to a reduction in the potential that limits the RDS during the OER. Furthermore, the CoNC carrier’s surface is characterized by pyrrole-N sites, which establish robust chemical bonds with the deposited RuIr nanocrystals. This results in a uniform dispersion of the RuIr catalyst on the CoNC substrate and a secure immobilization of the catalyst on the CoNC surface [227]. Another representative study synthesized hierarchical Co3O4 nanoplates assembled from ultrathin nanosheets by an etching coordination reorganization method using a Co-ZIF-67-based template, in addition to the effective incorporation of adsorbed metal atoms into the octahedral sites of Co3O4 (Fig. 13(d)). The Fe-doped Co3O4 layered hollow nanoplates, referred to as Fe-Co3O4 HHNPs, exhibit exceptional performance in the OER application owing to their favorable structural and compositional characteristics. At a current density of 10 mA cm–2, this material exhibits a remarkably low overpotential of only 262 mV, coupled with a Tafel slope measuring 43 mV dec–1 (Fig. 13(e)). Meanwhile, the Fe-Co3O4 HHNPs electrocatalyst was operated at current densities of 10, 50, and 100 mA cm–2 for 50 h without significant changes, showing good stability (Fig. 13(f)). This is ascribed to the exclusive morphological structure of Fe-Co3O4 HHNPs electrocatalyst, where the ultrathin nanosheets and the highly porous cross-channel structure expose many active sites, facilitating mass and charge transport [141]. In addition, many researchers have prepared a variety of SACs using MOFs as a template, and all of them showed good electrocatalytic OER performance (Fig. 14 ) [148,151,153,191,294–303]. By summarizing and studying the above classic cases, we found that the structure of SACs has an essential influence on their electrocatalytic OER performance. First, the heteroatoms can regulate the electron density of the metal SAs, etc., which can lower the reaction energy barrier and enhance the reactivity of SACs. Second, the active sites of SACs need to be coordinated with other atoms on the catalyst surface to improve the stability of the reactive active sites. In conclusion, SACs exhibit a well-defined active site and maximum atomic utilization. SACs originating from MOFs have promising applications in electrocatalytic OER. As mentioned above, SACs originating from MOFs have been applied to electrocatalytic HER and OER, and they have shown promising results in electrocatalytic overall water splitting as well. Yang and coworkers [267] developed a single-atom seeds strategy that allows the synthesis of SACs with ultra-low loadings by coordinated construction. Nickel hydroxide containing Ni2+ vacancies (VN-Ni(OH) x ) was obtained by electrochemical reduction of MOFs (Fig. 13(g)). Then, Pt SAs were inserted into the vacancies as seeds to form a Pt-O4 tetradentate structure, which firmly fixes the Pt SAs and avoids aggregation. The electrocatalyst, consisting of Pt-Ni(OH) x , was synthesized with an ultra-low loading of around 0.17 wt%. In the HER reaction, the electrocatalyst demonstrated a low overpotential of 58 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 in a 1 mol L–1 KOH electrolyte, as displayed in Fig. 13(h). Motivated by the impressive performance of the Pt-Ni(OH) x electrocatalyst in terms of HER/OER, the researchers constructed an electrolyzer in a two-electrode arrangement to facilitate monolithic hydrolysis. Fig. 13(i) shows that the Pt-Ni(OH)x electrocatalyst displayed an impressive electrocatalytic OER performance (η 10 = 1.47 V) [267]. Electrochemical water splitting has important value for the production of renewable energy [304–308]. The effectiveness of electrochemical overall water splitting is slowed by the overpotential necessary to overcome the energy barrier associated with the HER [309–312] and OER [313–316] applications. The use of universally applicable SACs is of utmost importance in achieving efficient and ecological energy conversion. Furthermore, the strategic development of SACs serves as a very practical approach to reducing overpotential [317–320]. The utilization of SACs originating from MOFs has led to notable progress in the realm of electrochemical water splitting. However, it is essential to acknowledge that more advancement is required before these findings can be effectively applied in practical contexts. An important issue is that researchers need to increase the yield of SACs while ensuring their activity and stability rather than conducting experiments in a laboratory setting, which would be a major breakthrough if this problem were overcome in the future. 5.3 SACs originating from MOFs for the ORR ORR is important as a cathode reaction in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) and rechargeable metal-air cells [321–325]. ORR usually has two pathways, where a two-electron (2e–) reaction produces H2O2 products [326–329], and a four-electron (4e–) reaction produces water [330–334]. The former is usually used to ensure environmentally friendly H2O2 synthesis, while the latter can be applied in energy conversion systems [335–338]. However, the central issue of ORR is to alter the sluggish kinetics, reduce the overpotential, and improve selectivity. Currently, SACs originating from MOFs are accepted as one of the most favorable alternatives to Pt-based electrocatalysts in ORR due to their tunable electronic/geometric properties and well-defined active sites [92,115,334]. For example, Zhang and coworkers used an anchoring with ligands approach to prepare O- and N-doped carbon nanorods using MOF-74 as a precursor and then prepared FeN4-O, N-doped carbon rods (FeN4-O-NCR) electrocatalyst by electrostatic adsorption and microwave-assisted carbonization steps. The FeN4-O-NCR electrocatalyst with axially bridged O lowers the d-band center position and increases the average valence of Fe, favorably tuning the adsorption energies of electrocatalytic ORR intermediates. The FeN4-O-NCR electrocatalyst that was developed exhibits a hierarchical porous structure, possesses a highly specific surface area, and includes a significant number of FeN4-O active sites. These characteristics contribute to the optimization of oxygen adsorption and activation, ultimately leading to an improvement in the electro-catalytic activity for the application ORR shown in Fig. 15(a) . The evaluation of electrocatalytic performance for the ORR application in an alkaline environment was carried out on the FeN4-O-NCR electrocatalyst. In Fig. 15(b), a significant kinetic current density of 39.56 mA cm–2 was observed at 0.9 V for the electrocatalyst FeN4-O-NCR, accompanied by an E onset of 1.050 V and a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.942 V. This value exceeded the kinetic current density of 2.00 mA cm–2 measured for Pt/C. Compared to the lower H2O2 yield of FeN4-O-NCR electrocatalyst, FeN4/CR electrocatalysts showed higher H2O2 yields at all tested potentials. Based on the calculations, the FeN4-O-NCR electrocatalyst reduces oxygen to OH– via a 4e– pathway (Fig. 15(c)). The power density of FeN4-O-NCR electrocatalyst as a zinc-air battery (ZAB) cathode electrocatalyst was 214.2 mW cm–2, which was better than that of the Pt/C electrocatalyst (104.2 mW cm–2) [339]. The porous structure facilitates oxygen adsorption and activation, while the pore size can be adjusted by altering the addition ratio of LiCl and KCl in the synthesis process. He and coworkers prepared nitrogen-doped graphene nanowebs (NGM) with tunable pore size by thermal exfoliation of Zn-ZIF nanoleaves (Zn-ZIF-L). Subsequently, FePc molecules were dispersed and immobilized on the NGM to prepare Fe SAs electrocatalyst (SA-Fe-NGM) with metal content up to 8.36 wt% by high-temperature pyrolysis. During the synthesis process, the pore size adjustment of NGM and high loading of Fe SAs were achieved by adjusting the ratio of LiCl and KCl, resulting in SA-Fe-NGM electrocatalyst exhibiting excellent electrocatalytic ORR activity in acidic media. Experiments using SA-Fe-NGM electrocatalyst found an E 1/2 of 0.83 V (vs. RHE). In addition, the H2/O2 fuel cell experiments reached a power density of 634 mW cm–2 [128]. In contrast to the above, the electrocatalytic ORR efficiency can also be significantly improved by increasing the electron transfer rate. Han and coworkers obtained N-doped carbon (NC) frameworks via ZIF-8 and subsequently prepared Se SAs@NC electrocatalyst by anchoring Se SAs to NC frameworks using a stepwise pyrolysis-reduction strategy. First, NC was prepared by high-temperature pyrolysis using zeolitic imidazole framework ZIF-8. Then Se SAs were formed by evaporation and reduction of SeO2 (by NC reduction) at high-temperature, and these Se SAs were immobilized on the NC surface to form Se@NC-1000 electrocatalyst. DFT calculations showed that the Se species in the prepared electrocatalyst could act as the active center of electrocatalytic ORR, and the authors simulated the character of Se species in the electrocatalytic ORR process in the Se@NC-1000 electrocatalyst (Fig. 15(d)). The Se@NC-1000 electrocatalyst exhibited an electrocatalytic ORR E 1/2 of up to 0.85 V, similar to that of Pt/C (Fig. 15(e)). The Se@NC-1000 electrocatalyst exhibits faster ORR kinetics than Se@NC-900, Pt/C, and NC electrocatalysts, as evident from the Tafel slope depicted in Fig. 15(f). Meanwhile, the ZAB with Se@NC-1000 electrocatalyst showed significantly higher discharge power density (176.9 vs. 115.4 mW cm–2) and long-term durability than Pt/C. This may be due to the presence of plentiful defects and graphitic carbon in the Se@NC-1000 electrocatalyst, which may help to improve the electron transfer capacity and promote electrocatalytic ORR [340]. In addition to defects and graphitic carbon favoring increased electron transport rates, one-dimensional structures also tend to increase electron transport rates. Xu and coworkers prepared Fe-N-C hollow nanorods (Fe1-N-C HNRs) electrocatalyst, which used ZIF-8 as a sacrificial template to prepare N-doped carbon-hollow nanorods (N-C HNRs) were employed to capture Fe ions from a FeCl3·6H2O solution, followed by a carbonization process to immobilize Fe atoms. Outstanding ORR performance was demonstrated by the Fe1-N-C HNRs electrocatalyst, with E 1/2 values of 0.91 and 0.8 V (vs. RHE) achieved under alkaline and acidic electrolyte conditions, respectively. An exceptional power density of 208 mW cm–2 was observed when the Fe1-N-C HNRs electrocatalyst was employed as a cathode electrocatalyst. The material’s exceptional electrocatalytic ORR performance is likely attributed to the ultra-high accessible surface, the abundance of Fe-N4 active sites, and the increased electron transport facilitated by the 1D structure [127]. To date, SACs originating from MOFs with efficient electrocatalytic activity are the effective strategies to achieve cost-competitive electrocatalysts for fuel cell applications, which have been extensively investigated by many researchers. The coordination structure is one of the key factors affecting the electrocatalytic ORR performance of SACs. The effect of coordination structure on electrocatalytic ORR performance is mainly reflected in the electronic structure of the SACs surface. From the perspective of an electronic structure, the coordination structure can regulate the electron density and its distribution pattern on the SACs’s surface. Appropriate electron density and distribution can optimize the oxygen adsorption capacity of SACs and thus improve the electrocatalytic ORR activity. Some coordination structures can achieve this goal by adjusting parameters such as electron affinity and bond length. In conclusion, M-N/P (S, O)-C coordination structures containing heteroatoms such as P, S, and O perform excellently in electrocatalytic ORR. These structures can provide appropriate electronic structures and thus enhance the electrocatalytic ORR activity of SACs. Recent SACs originating from MOFs for electrocatalytic ORR are summarized in Table 2 . We have analyzed and summarized the above classic cases of SACs originating from MOFs applied to electrocatalytic ORR and the excellent research results in recent years. We have found that excellent electrocatalytic activity can be achieved by coordinating individual metal atoms with C and N atoms or combining P/O and N atoms, thereby tuning the metal active center’s electron density and d-band centers (Fig. 16 ). SACs originating from MOFs have excellent electrocatalytic ORR performance and have achieved remarkable results in the field of metal-air batteries and fuel cells. However, we also found a problem in that the use of MOF derivatives as carriers for SACs by most researchers usually requires a multi-step preparation process, which is not only time-consuming but also consumes a large number of materials to some extent. The above problem requires researchers to consider whether the preparation process can be reduced to achieve the same effect. For example, MOFs can be used directly as carriers for SACs instead of using their derivatives as carriers. SACs have achieved excellent results in directions such as OER [358] and ORR [359] and are also a rising star in bifunctional (OER and ORR) electrocatalysts [360–362]. For example, Li and coworkers used a combination of polymer coating, wet chemisorption, ammonia, and pyrolysis treatment to fabricate an atomically dispersed Fe site on mesoporous carbon nitride catalysts in which an O atom is coordinated to a Fe atom (Fe SACs/NC) and perpendicular to the Fe1-N4 plane (Fig. 15(g)). The Fe SAs/NC samples containing Fe1N4O1 sites show remarkable ORR performance across all pH levels. In acidic, basic, and neutral electrolytes, the half-wave potentials were measured to be 0.83, 0.93, and 0.75 V (vs. RHE), respectively. Furthermore, OER activity overpotential as low as 320 mV at 10 mA cm–2 under alkaline conditions was observed in the Fe SAs/NC samples, as depicted in Fig. 15(h). Impressive performance characteristics were exhibited by the Fe SAs/NC electrocatalyst, including a peak power density of 306.1 mW cm–2, specific capacitance of 746.9 mAh g–1, and exceptional durability of ZAB, which endured for more than 315 h. These achievements outperformed the Pt/C+RuO2 electrocatalyst. The superior electrocatalytic efficiency of the Fe SAs/NC electrocatalyst in terms of ORR/OER may be ascribed to its notable characteristics, including a substantial specific surface area and mesoporosity. These attributes enable effective mass transfer and optimal exploitation of metal sites [298]. One instance where a substantial specific surface area is used to enhance the efficiency of single atoms is seen in the usage of atomically distributed Fe-Ni SAs that are embedded inside an N-doped carbon matrix, often referred to as the FeNi SAs/NC electrocatalyst. The specific preparation method of FeNi SAs/NC electrocatalysts is to synthesize novel bimetallic MOFs by conventional chemical co-precipitation method and then prepare them successfully by coating, pyrolysis, acid etching, and annealing processes. FeNi SAs/NC electrocatalyst has hollow interiors and porous supporting carbon groups, thus improving atomic utilization. At the same time, introducing Ni can modulate the electronic structure of the Fe sites and lower the reaction energy barrier, thus improving the electrocatalytic activity. Specifically, the FeNi SAs/NC electrocatalyst has an OER overpotential of only 270 mV at 10 mA cm–2. It shows excellent activity in the ORR with an E onset of 0.98 V and an E 1/2 of 0.84 V vs. RHE. Similarly, the assembled Al-air batterie (AAB) has a power density of 45.25 mW cm–2 and a specific capacity of 1576.4 mAh g–1, while the quasi-solid-state ZAB with FeNi SAs/NC has an open-circuit potential of 1.45 V, a power density of 42.22 mW cm–2, and more than 45 h stability [297]. It can be seen that the introduction of Ni can modulate the electronic structure of Fe, thus lowering the reaction energy barrier and promoting the electrocatalytic reaction. Similarly, the combination of Co and Fe is also favorable to the electrocatalytic reaction. Bu and coworkers proposed a “pre-constrained metal twinning” strategy to prepare continuous FeN4 and CoN4 bimetallic atom-centered electrocatalyst (FeCo-DACs/NC) with uniform conformations by implanting metal phthalocyanine dimer molecules into ZIF-8 as pyrolytic precursors for controlled synthesis and uniform dispersion of CoN4- and FeN4-containing sites. When combined, Fe and Co have a synergistic effect that improves electrocatalytic efficiency by optimizing the d-band center location of the metal site and balancing the free energy of the *O intermediate. In 0.1 mol L–1 KOH, the ORR activity of the FeCo-DACs/NC electrocatalyst was measured, and it was shown to have superior E onset (0.984 V vs. RHE) and E 1/2 (0.877 V vs. RHE) values compared to those of the Pt/C electrocatalyst. The OER activity of FeCo-DACs/NC electrocatalysts was measured in 1 mol L–1 KOH, and only a current density of 10 mA cm–2 was required at an overpotential of 370 mV. At the same time, FeCo-DACs/NC electrocatalyst was discharged at approximately 1.03 V at 50 mA cm–2 with a maximum power density of 175 mW cm–2 at the air cathode. The discharge charge from 0.851 to 0.914 V was almost negligible after approximately 480 cycles [148]. Different from the above, Shao and coworkers formed a nanoarchitecture of ZIF-67 with N-doped carbon nanotubes/polypyrrole (CNT/PPy-ZIF-67) by self-assembly, followed by the preparation of biphasic carbon consisting of CNT-supported monoatomic Co sites and carbon polyhedron anchored nano-Co species (denoted as CNT/SAC-Co/NCP) by pyrolysis (Fig. 15(i)). A minimal disparity in overpotential, measuring 0.74 V, was observed between the OER potential (η 10 = 1.61 V) at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 and the ORR potential (E 1/2 = 0.870 V) when the electrocatalyst CNT/SAC-Co/NCP was utilized. Similar to Pt/C, the ZAB using CNT/SAC-Co/NCP had an open-circuit voltage of 1.45 V. In Fig. 15(j), the ZAB of the bifunctional catalyst showed a large power density of 172 mW cm–2. The charge-discharge potential difference of CNT/SAC-Co/NCP was a notably smaller and more stable charge-discharge potential gap in comparison to Pt/C+Ir/C. The good performance exhibited by the CNT/SAC-Co/NCP electrocatalyst may be attributed to the CNT connecting the two independent phases, which promotes electron transfer and facilitates the electrocatalytic reaction [299]. Due to their exceptional electrocatalytic activity in ORR/OER, SACs originating from MOFs have been extensively studied. The following section summarizes and lists recent SACs originating from MOFs for OER/ORR in Table 3 . We have analyzed and summarized the above classic cases of SACs originating from MOFs applied to electrocatalytic ORR/OER and the excellent research results in recent years. SACs originating from MOFs have excellent electrocatalytic ORR/OER performance, but some problems exist. Some SACs originating from MOFs usually need to be acid-washed or calcined (under an ammonia atmosphere). The waste acid and tail gas generated in these experiments can pollute the environment if not handled properly and consume more resources in the process, which requires researchers to think about whether the same effect can be achieved by optimizing the preparation process, e.g., solving the problem by adjusting the appropriate organic ligands to disperse and immobilize the SAs at the source instead of consuming the resources at a later stage. 5.4 SACs originating from MOFs for the CO2RR A worldwide energy crisis and severe climate change have been triggered by the excessive CO2 in the atmosphere caused by the overexploitation and usage of fossil fuels [363–367]. In order to deal with the problem of rising energy demand [368–371] and limited energy storage from resources like fossil fuels [371–374], it is crucial to convert CO2 into valuable chemical compounds in a highly selective and efficient way [375–379]. Photocatalytic, thermos catalytic, and electrocatalytic processes may all be used to transform CO2. Among them, electrochemical CO2 reduction is a promising method for CO2 utilization, which can directly convert CO2 into valuable chemicals [380–383]. The advancement of electrocatalysts is vital for efficient electrocatalytic CO2RR [384–387]. SACs originating from MOFs are receiving increasing attention in the field of multiphase catalysis, especially in the field of CO2 conversion [388–390]. For instance, using ZIF-8 as a mold, Hou and coworkers produced a monovalent Zn electrocatalyst distributed at the atomic level and anchored to nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets (Zn/NC NSs) by molten salt-assisted solid-phase pyrolysis. Outstanding electrocatalytic performance for the reduction of CO2 was exhibited by the Zn/NC NSs at an overpotential of –0.96 V, yielding a current density of 50 mA cm–2 with a CO Faraday efficiency (FECO) of about 95%. Additionally, high stability was observed for the Zn/NC NSs electrocatalyst, as evidenced by 2000 s reaction duration within a potential range of 10 to 100 mA cm–2. The reduction of CO2 to CO was facilitated by the unique structure of the Zn/NC NSs electrocatalysts, which promoted the protonation of *CO2 and the generation of COOH* intermediates [133]. The unique structure of Zn/NC NSs electrocatalyst can accelerate RDS. Another representative work is the modulation of the structural morphology of the electrocatalyst as well as a large number of active sites, which has also achieved remarkable results in accelerating RDS. Hou and coworkers also created a tin-nitrogen site-containing porous N-doped carbon nanofibers (Sn/NCNFs) electrocatalyst by combining a basic electrostatic spinning method with the pyrolysis of nanofibers comprised of polyacrylonitrile (PAN), SnCl2-2H2O, and ZIF-8 sacrificial templates. The porous structure of the fibers and the number of Sn-N active sites exposed (as shown in Fig. 17(a) ) allow the customized Sn/NCNFs electrocatalyst to speed up the hydrolysis and subsequent formation of *COOH in the intermediates. The Sn/NCNFs electrocatalyst, as illustrated in Fig. 17(b), reduces carbon dioxide with a high FECO of 96.5%. As can be seen in Fig. 17(c), it has a very low Tafel slope of 68.8 mV dec–1. The partial current density of CO in a flow cell operating at –0.7 V is also rather high, at 100.6 mA cm–2 [157]. In addition to exposing many reaction sites by modulating the morphology of the electrocatalyst, reaction sites can also be exposed by modulating pores or defects. Li and coworkers [393] prepared a bimetallic electrocatalyst anchored on mesoporous N-doped carbon (Cu-In-NC) by constructing adjacent Cu and in SAs using an in situ node evolution method to pyrolyze polymetallic MOFs (Cu-In-ZIF-8). The introduction of Cu and In into the ZIF-8 backbone resulted in the formation of a large number of defects during thermal conversion, leading to the formation of a large number of mesopores, which can maximize the exposure of active sites and promote mass transfer in catalytic reactions. A high faradaic efficiency of 96% at –0.7 V (vs. RHE) was achieved with the Cu-In-NC electrocatalyst. Furthermore, a high level of persistence was observed in the Cu-In-NC electrocatalyst, with 90% of its initial efficiency being retained after 12 h of electrolysis [393]. The highly defective hierarchically microporous carbon was also modified by Jiang and coworkers to include isolated and dense single-atom Ni-N3 sites (Ni-SACs/HMMNC-800). The mesoporous SiO2-coated ZIF-8 (ZIF-8@mesoSiO2) was first pyrolyzed, and due to the evaporation of Zn ions during the pyrolysis process, hierarchically micro-mesoporous N-doped porous carbon particles covering the mesoporous SiO2 were produced (HMMNC@mesoSiO2). Afterward, SiO2 was removed by acid (HF) etching to obtain HMMNC. Subsequently, a combination of encapsulation confinement and anchoring with ligands was used to encapsulate urea and NiCl2·6H2O on an HMMNC polyhedral containing many defects, followed by the generation of Ni-SAs/HMMNC electrocatalyst during the pyrolysis process. The Ni-SAs/HMMNC-800 electrocatalyst undergoes four main steps in the electrocatalytic CO2RR process (Fig. 17(d)). In this process, the Ni-SAs/HMMNC-800 electrocatalyst exhibits excellent electrocatalytic CO2RR activity and selectivity, achieving an ultra-high FECO of ≍99.5% at –0.7 V (vs. RHE) (FECO values > 90% over a wide potential range) and good durability in long-term CO2RR experiments (Fig. 17(e)). In the electrocatalyst Ni-SAs/HMMNC-800, the binding of Ni-N3 molecules to the adjacent defective structures is responsible for reducing the energy barrier associated with COOH* formation, while the presence of a substantial quantity of mesopores in the defective structure exposes a greater number of reaction sites and expedites charge transfer during the electrocatalytic CO2RR process. This results in a notable enhancement in the performance of electrocatalytic CO2RR [391]. Lowering the reaction energy barrier for electrocatalytic CO2RR is crucial, but inhibiting the side reaction (e.g., HER) while decreasing the reaction energy barrier is also integral. Using ZIF as a template, He and coworkers prepared a novel NiN4/CuN4 two-site electrocatalyst (Ni/Cu-N-C) using a combination of in situ node evolution and encapsulation confinement to introduce Ni and Cu into ZIF, respectively. This unique structure of the prepared NiN4 and CuN4 enhanced the binding of the intermediate (*COOH) to the Ni center, lowered the energy barrier to the formation of *COOH at the Ni site, and inhibited the electrocatalytic HER, thus facilitating the formation of CO (Fig. 17(f)). Thus, Ni/Cu-N-C electrocatalyst containing NiN4/CuN4 molecules exhibit a high FECO of more than 95% (up to 99.2% at –0.79 V vs. RHE) at potential from –0.39 to –1.09 V vs. RHE, a TOF of 6895 h–1 at –1.09 V vs. RHE (Fig. 17(g)), and endurance of 60 h [392]. Moreover, Zheng and coworkers [394] prepared axially O-coordinated FeN4 (O-Fe-N-C) using oxygen- and nitrogen-enriched MOFs (IRMOF-3) as precursors by the encapsulation confinement method. The O-Fe-N-C electrocatalyst showed excellent CO2RR activity in 0.5 mol L–1 NaHCO3 solution with high FECO (95%) and 30 h stability at –0.50 V (vs. RHE). The axial O-coordination therein not only weakened the binding energy of CO but also inhibited hydrogen production [394]. In another study, 2Bn-Cu@UiO-67 electrocatalyst was created by Wang and coworkers by employing UiO-67 as a template for encapsulating Cu SACs coupled by N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC). Compared to 2Bn-ACu@UiO-67 electrocatalyst, 2Bn-Cu@UiO-67 achieves 81% CO2RR to CH4 FE (around 70% CH4 selectivity across the full potential range) at –1.5 V vs. RHE with a current density of 420 mA cm–2, and has a TOF of 16.3 s–1. The σ enrichment of NHCs increased the surface charge density of Cu SACs in the 2Bn-Cu@UiO-67 electrocatalyst, thus optimizing the adsorption of intermediates (CHO*) during CH4 formation and the micro reaction chambers provided by MOFs to synergistically promote electrocatalytic CO2RR [41]. In summary, SACs have taken their place in the field of electrocatalytic CO2RR due to their unique ligand environment [395–397]. MOFs have chemically tunable properties that can be modified at the molecular level to anchor reasonable metal species as well as change the appropriate pore size. These would be beneficial to improve the selectivity and efficiency of SACs for CO2RR. The electrocatalytic CO2RR based on SACs originating from MOFs is analyzed here and summarized in Table 4 . We have analyzed and summarized the above classic cases of SACs originating from MOFs applied to electrocatalytic CO2RR and the excellent research results in recent years. The above summary shows that when the coordination structure of SACs changes, their electronic structure and chemical activity will also change accordingly, thus affecting the performance of the electrocatalytic CO2RR. The coordination structure affects the electronic structure of the active center: The coordination structure of SAs directly affects the electron distribution and energy state of the active center of the SACs. The SAs’s electronic structure can be changed by selecting and adjusting coordination atoms, which in turn affects the electron transfer and chemical reaction pathway in the electrocatalytic CO2RR process. Different coordination structures may lead to different reaction paths and product selectivity. For example, some coordination structures may promote the generation of CO, CH4, etc., while others may be more favorable to the generation of C2+ products, etc. By adjusting the coordination structure of SAs, the selective control of the electrocatalytic CO2RR products can be realized. Notably, in the above cases, the N2O2-coordinated Fe site has the best electrocatalytic CO2RR performance, the ratio of the number of coordinated N-sites to O-sites around the Fe site is very important for regulating the electrocatalytic activity and selectivity for the conversion of CO2 to CO, and the N2O2-coordinated Fe site has lower free energy in the COOH* formation and CO desorption steps, which speeds up the reaction kinetics and improves the electrocatalytic CO2RR performance (Fig. 18 ) [124]. SACs originating from MOFs have excellent activity and selectivity when used for electrocatalytic CO2RR, but there are some problems. For example, most carriers using MOF derivatives as SACs usually require high-temperature calcination during the preparation process, which consumes a lot of energy to some extent. This question requires researchers to consider whether the same effect could be achieved by reducing energy loss, such as hydrothermal or microwave synthesis instead of high-temperature calcination, or by using MOFs directly as carriers for SACs instead of their derivatives. 5.5 SACs originating from MOFs for the NRR Ammonia is known to be one of the most significant products in the chemical industry and agriculture. It has been extensively used as a source of synthetic fertilizers, plastics, pharmaceuticals, explosives, etc. [412–415]. The Haber-Bosch process, utilized in most commercial NH3 production today, is notoriously energy-intensive [416–419]. Therefore, it is worthwhile to explore sustainable strategies and efficient catalysts for ammonia synthesis [420,421]. Among the developed schemes, the reduction of N2 to NH3 using electrocatalysis is considered a sustainable pathway for the production of ammonia [422,423]. However, it also faces significant problems, including low current density and low FE [424]. Recently, SACs originating from MOFs have exhibited special electronic structures, tunable coordination structures, and high atomic utilization and are widely used as electrocatalysts for NRR. For example, Sun and coworkers prepared a Ru@ZrO2/NC electrocatalyst using an anchoring with ligands strategy to encapsulate Ru ions using aminated UiO-66 as a template, followed by washing and annealing (Fig. 19(a) ). The NH3 yield of the Ru@ZrO2/NC electrocatalyst reached 3.665 mgNH3 h–1 mgRu – 1 at an overpotential of –0.21 V. It is noteworthy that the FE of NH3 was about 21% at a lower overpotential (0.17 V) (Fig. 19(b)). This excellent activity is related to the small size of Ru and the facilitating effect of ZrO2 (suppression of HER) [425]. The above work suggests that electrocatalytic HER is a competing reaction for electrocatalytic NRR, and the action of ZrO2 inhibits the occurrence of electrocatalytic HER. Similarly, metal SAs can promote electrocatalytic NRR and inhibit electrocatalytic HER simultaneously through a rational coordination structure. Liu and coworkers [426] prepared an electrocatalyst anchored to a single Fe atom site on an N-doped carbon framework (ISAS-Fe/NC) using an in situ nodal evolution method, in which the bimetallic Fe/Zn-ZIF-8 was first prepared, followed by carbonization and acid washing (Fig. 19(c)). The atomically dispersed Fe in the ISAS-Fe/NC electrocatalyst is coordinated with four N atoms, activating the N2 molecule without exhibiting reduction reaction properties. The ISAS-Fe/NC electrocatalyst achieved high FENH3 (18.6 ± 0.8%) and NH3 yields (62.9 ± 2.7 μg h–1 mgcat. –1) in a neutral aqueous electrolyte at room temperature and –0.4 V (vs. RHE). The ISAS-Fe/NC electrocatalyst was subjected to a 24 h electrocatalytic NRR test, and a slight decay in current density was observed. Simultaneously, the change in FE was negligible, showing a high degree of stability (Fig. 19(d)) [426]. Moreover, Zeng and coworkers [427] synthesized Ru-containing derivatives of ZIF-8 by replacing part of Zn(NO3)2 with Ru(acac)3, and then Ru SAs distributed on N-doped carbon (Ru SAs/N-C) were obtained by pyrolysis. The Ru SAs/N-C electrocatalyst had good electrocatalytic NRR performance, and the produces NH3 current density, and FENH3 of the Ru SAs/N-C electrocatalyst was higher than those of the Ru NPs/N-C electrocatalyst for all applied potentials. Notably, the yield of Ru SACs/N-C electrocatalyst reached 120.9 μgNH3 mgcat. –1 h–1 for NH3 production. The excellent performance of Ru SACs/N-C electrocatalyst in electrocatalytic NRR may be attributed to the fact that the ΔG for N2 dissociation (RDS) on Ru (101) and Ru1-N4 were 0.91 and 0.77 eV, respectively, which were higher than that on Ru1-N3 (0.73 eV) [427]. In another representative endeavor, prepared atomically dispersed Zn(I) anchored onto hollow porous N-doped carbon nanofibers (Zn1N-C) by Hou and coworkers by using a ZIF-8 template and combining electrostatic spinning and pyrolysis strategies (Fig. 19(e)). LSV tests on the electrocatalyst of Zn1N-C in N2 and Ar-saturated solutions showed some differences in current densities, which can be regarded as additional current densities generated by electrocatalytic NRR (Fig. 19(f)). The excellent electrocatalytic NRR activity of the Zn1N-C electrocatalyst was demonstrated by the high NH3 yield of ≍16.1 µg h–1 mgcat –1 with 11.8% FE in an alkaline medium at a potential of –0.3 V (Fig. 19(g)). The possible synergistic effect between the dispersed active Zn-N4 sites and the neighboring graphite N atoms is related to the acceleration of the kinetics of the key hydrogenation step in the NRR process and the reduction of the energy barrier for subsequent *NNH formation by the graphite N atoms adjacent to Zn-N4 [134]. In summary, electrocatalytic NRR is an attractive method for synthesizing NH3. SACs originating from MOFs have low costs in NRR. However, we also found a problem: compared with other electrocatalytic reactions, most researchers used SACs originating from MOFs for electrocatalytic NRR with lower FE and yield, which makes SACs originating from MOFs still have a long way to go for industrial application in electrocatalytic NRR, and researchers need to make efforts to study and solve the above problems. 5.6 Others The above applications of SACs in various electrocatalytic fields indicate that SAC is gradually becoming a new research hot spot and frontier field in electrocatalysis [428,429]. This may be because SACs combine the advantages of both homogeneous and multiphase catalysts: (1) High atomic utilization (~100%) with lower coordination of a single atom makes it extremely easy to interact chemically with the carriers and reactants, thus exhibiting ultra-high intrinsic activity. (2) SACs have a highly homogeneous and clearly single-atom active site with ultra-high selectivity. (3) The SACs are easy to separate and have good stability and reusability [430,431]. This gives SACs good performance not only in electrocatalysis but also in photocatalysis, thermos catalysis, and enzyme catalysis. For example, Li and coworkers [432] prepared isolated single Ru sites supported on N-doped porous carbon (Ru SAs/N-C) by utilizing the strong coordination between free amine groups (–NH2) and Ru3+ on the metal-organic framework backbone to prevent the formation of Ru clusters (Fig. 20(a) ). Since the unique single Ru site with single N coordination in Ru SAs/N-C catalyst can be used as a semi-homogeneous catalyst, the chemoselective hydrogenation catalytic reactions of functionalized quinolones can be efficiently carried out. As shown in Fig. 20(b), the selectivity of py-THQ using Ru SAs/N-C catalyst was more than 99%, and its activity and selectivity remained unchanged after 5 cycles of hydrogenation reaction. The selectivity of py-THQ decreased after 5 cycles of the same hydrogenation reaction over Ru clusters supported on N-doped porous carbon (Ru NCs/N-C) catalyst (Fig. 20(c)) [432]. To avoid the use of noble metals, the Gascon group synthesized a catalyst with atomically dispersed Co-N x sites in mesoporous N-doped carbon matrices (named Co@mesoNC) by hydrolysis of tetramethyl orthosilicate (TMOS) followed by high-temperature pyrolysis and SiO2 leaching in a Zn/Co bimetallic MOF. This Co@mesoNC catalyst allows the selective hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline (> 99% selectivity) under mild conditions. This may be attributed to mesopores that improve the mass transfer of reactants and products and the accessibility of reaction-active Co-N x sites, significantly reducing deactivation due to clogging [435]. SACs have also shown surprising attraction in photocatalysis due to their high efficiency, stability, and controllability. Liu and coworkers [433] obtained a CuSA-TiO2 photocatalyst by maximally immobilizing Cu SAs on TiO2 using MOF structures with large specific surface areas as intermediates. The photocatalytic hydrogen production performance is excellent due to the highly dispersed Cu SAs on TiO2 and the efficient electron transfer through the Cu2+-Cu+ process (Fig. 20(d)). The H2 evolution rate under simulated solar irradiation reaches 101.7 mmol g–1 h–1 with excellent stability and an apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) of up to 56% at 365 nm (Fig. 20(e)) [433]. Compared to block MOF materials with hindered mass transfer and limited accessibility of active sites, 2D MOF materials can address this limitation well. Zhou and coworkers directly constructed ultrathin 2D MOF nanosheets with Pt single atomic coordination using a surfactant-stabilized coordination strategy with PtII tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (PtTCPP) as the linker and Cu2-(COO)4 as the metal node. A photocatalyst named PtSA-MNSs was obtained using the above method. Under visible light (λ > 420 nm) irradiation, the PtSA-MNSs photocatalysts achieved photocatalytic H2 evolution rates up to 11320 μmol g–1 h–1 by water splitting [436]. SACs have a tunable ligand structure similar to various metalloenzymes with specific metal ions as active sites and are embedded in the protein framework. For example, Li and coworkers prepared a FeN3P single-atom peroxidase nanozyme (FeN3P-SAzyme) by precisely coordinating P and N to modulate the Fe SA active center (Fig. 20(f)). FeN3P-SAzyme, prepared by precise design of the electronic and geometrical structure of the active center, possesses peroxidase catalytic activity and kinetic properties similar to those of the natural enzyme and can be used as an effective therapeutic strategy to inhibit tumor cell growth in vitro and in vivo. The catalytic activity of FeN3P-SAzyme (316 U mg– 1) was more than 30-fold higher than that of Fe3O4 nanozyme and nearly 10-fold higher than that of FeN4-SAzyme, as measured by the absorption intensity of the nanozyme-catalyzed colorimetric reaction (Fig. 20(g)) [434]. Also using SACs to mimic the enzyme, Zhao and coworkers generated well-defined single-atom enzyme (OxgeMCC-r SAE) by replacing part of the metal node Co in Mn3[Co(CN)6]2 MOF with part of Ru while self-assembling with poly-vinylpyrrolidone (PVP) polymer and chlorine e6 (Ce6) photosensitizer in the collective coordination and other non-covalent interactions. Due to the inherent porous nature of MOF and the six unsaturated Ru-C6 coordination sites, OxgenMCC-r rapidly decomposes H2O2, thereby overcoming tumor hypoxia. Specifically, 50% degradation of H2O2 (10 mmol L–1) was achieved within 20 min. Furthermore, the catalytic reaction rate constant of OxgeMCC-r was calculated to be 0.041 min–1, which is higher than that of MnO2 (0.029 min–1), which is widely used at the same concentration of the active ingredient [437]. In summary, the reasons and properties of SACs originating from MOFs showing good performance in photocatalysis, thermos catalysis, and enzyme catalysis mainly include high specific surface area, abundant active sites, tunable structure of reaction active center ligands, and so on. We have analyzed and summarized the above classic cases of SACs originating from MOFs applied to various electrocatalytic reactions (HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR) and the excellent research results in recent years. SACs originating from MOFs have excellent activity, high TOF, good selectivity, and outstanding stability when used in various electrocatalytic reactions but have some problems. For example, SACs originating from MOFs may consume many materials during their preparation (many synthesis steps), have high energy consumption (high-temperature calcination), pollute the environment (acid washing, ammonia as a protective gas for calcination, etc.), have low yields, and are currently under laboratory conditions (not industrialize), which require in-depth studies by researchers to solve the above problems. 6 Reaction mechanism of SACs for electrocatalytic applications Electrocatalytic reactions play a crucial role in energy conversion processes such as batteries [294,438,439] and overall water splitting to produce hydrogen [18,440,441], among others [442]. Understanding the electrocatalytic reaction mechanism can help optimize energy conversion efficiency, energy sustainability, and environmental friendliness. Specifically, mechanistic studies of electrocatalytic reactions help to reveal the reaction pathways, thus enabling effective control of the reaction process. By gaining a deeper understanding of the reaction pathways, electrocatalysts can be better designed, and reaction conditions can be controlled so that specific reactions can be carried out efficiently. The study of electrocatalytic reaction mechanisms helps to deepen our understanding of electrochemical reaction processes, including basic processes such as electron transfer and proton transfer etc. Determination of the active site in a reaction is crucial for a comprehensive understanding of the electrocatalytic reaction mechanism. SACs are known for their atomic-level catalytic activity and offer a convenient means to identify the reactive active site by integrating advanced characterization techniques with DFT calculations. For example, by depositing iron precursors onto porous carbon (P-C) carriers, Fe1(OH) x /P-C electrocatalyst was obtained, which exhibited excellent electrocatalytic OER performance with an overpotential of only 320 mV at 10 mA cm–2 current intensity. In order to gain insight into the reasons for the good electrocatalytic OER performance of the Fe1(OH) x /P-C electrocatalyst, the authors performed a series of characterization tests. The AC HAADF-STEM results of Fe1(OH) x /P-C electrocatalyst showed that Fe in Fe1(OH) x /P-C electrocatalyst is distributed as atoms on the P-C substrate, which undoubtedly provides a great help in determining the reactive active sites. Meanwhile, the valence and coordination structures of Fe atoms in Fe1(OH) x /P-C electrocatalyst was tested by using XANES and EXAFS, which undoubtedly took a step forward to find out the reasons for the excellent electrocatalytic OER performance of Fe1(OH) x /P-C electrocatalyst. Finally, the authors elucidated the valence changes of iron during the reaction and the roles played by various components in the Fe1(OH) x /P-C electrocatalyst during the electrocatalytic OER reaction by DFT calculations. Some characterizations and DFT calculations determined the electrocatalytic OER process of Fe1(OH) x /P-C electrocatalyst. The Fe1(OH) x /P-C electrocatalyst followed a conventional four-step electrocatalytic OER process, in which Fe3+ was the active center (Fig. 21(a) ) [443]. SACs can be reaction-active sites at the oxidizing end of electrocatalytic reactions. At the same time, SACs can also be used as reaction active sites at the reducing end of the electrocatalytic reaction to obtain good electrocatalytic activity. Wang and coworkers constructed SACs (Ni-N4-C10) with specific coordination environments by encapsulating Ni2+ as a self-precursor into the cavity of ZIF-8 and anchoring it to a three-dimensional N-doped carbon framework. The Ni-N4-C10 electrocatalyst exhibits high ORR activity in alkaline solution due to the fast electron transfer rate and suitable electronic structure of the single atomic Ni reaction active site. The observation of isolated bright spots in the AC HAADF-STEM confirmed the presence of Ni in the Ni-N4-C10 electrocatalyst in a single atomic form. The chemical states of the elements in the Ni-N4-C10 electrocatalyst was investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), EXAFS, and XANES. After determining the physical/chemical structure of the Ni-N4-C10 electrocatalyst, the DFT was performed to investigate further the reaction mechanism of the Ni-N4-C10 electrocatalyst in the electrocatalytic ORR direction. First, the Ni-N-C structure requires an energy barrier of 0.369 eV to initiate the first electron transfer step (O2 + H2O + e– + * → *OOH + OH–, adsorption sites: *); moreover, the second electron transfer step has the largest energy barrier, ΔG = 0.597 eV (*OOH + e– → *O + OH–), i.e., the RDS. The following two steps are *O + H2O + e– → *OH + OH– and *OH + e– → * + OH– (Fig. 21(b)) [142]. Wang and coworkers utilized four N to coordinate with Au to form a reactive site and anchored it in Zr porphyrin MOF hollow nanotubes (HNTM) (named HNTM-Au-SA). The interesting thing is, when HNTM-Au-SA was used as an electrocatalyst for the CO2RR, it was found that the porphyrin was not only a ligand but also a photo switch that regulated the path of electron transfer to the metal center. The TOF of the HNTM-Au-SA electrocatalyst was as high as 37069 h–1 at –1.1 V, and the FECO was 94.2% at –0.9 V. Under visible light, the TOF and FECO of the HNTM-Au-SA electrocatalyst were similar to those at a potential reduction of about 130 mV. The overall conversion of CO2 to CO is a two-electron, two-proton process. The rate-determining step in the process is the first proton-coupled electron transfer step, i.e., the conversion of adsorbed *CO2 to *COOH, but among the electrocatalysts that the authors have compared, the HNTM-Co-SA electrocatalyst shows the smallest change in free energy. Notably, the metal sites in HNTM-M-SA are coordinated by four N atoms so that two CO2 molecules can be adsorbed on both sides of the porphyrin plane for electrocatalytic CO2RR during the reduction reaction. This led to a decrease in the RDS of the HNTM-Au-SA electrocatalyst in electrocatalytic CO2RR, resulting in a good electrocatalytic CO2RR performance. The electrocatalytic CO2RR mechanism of the HNTM-Au-SA electrocatalyst is shown in Fig. 21(c), in which each Au atom adsorbs two CO2 molecules and synergistically catalyzes their reduction [404]. From the above classic cases, it can be found that SACs exhibit good electrocatalytic activity at both oxidizing and reducing ends. The sea urchin-like nano-tube hierarchical structures (UNT Co SAs/N-C) electrocatalyst prepared by Huang and coworkers showed good electrocatalytic activity at both oxidation and reduction ends. After XAFS and DFT analyses, it was shown that the prepared UNT Co SAs/N-C electrocatalyst exhibited excellent performance in ORR/OER, which was attributed to the precise local coordination of CoN4, the neatly aligned carbon substrate due to the structure of MOFs, and the high-quality SA dispersion. Fig. 21(d) shows the reaction mechanism of electrocatalytic ORR/OER over UNT Co SAs/N-C electrocatalyst. UNT Co SAs/N-C electrocatalyst with CoN4 coordination structures has equivalent free energy drops at each electron transfer step, approaching the ideal free energy path. The adsorption capacity of UNT Co SAs/N-C for O* was lower than that of Co metals by DOS calculations, which undoubtedly favors the formation of OH* (OOH*) intermediates from adsorbed O*. The above results are consistent with the experimental results that the UNT Co SAs/N-C electrocatalyst with CoN4 molecular configuration have good electrocatalytic activity in the electrocatalytic ORR/OER direction [301]. From the above analysis, we found that the monometallic active sites in SACs are usually the active sites where reduction and oxidation reactions occur when electrocatalysts undergo electrocatalytic reactions. Due to the tunable ligand structure of SAs in the preparation of SACs and the tunable pore structure of MOF-generated SACs, SACs have excellent activity, high TOF, good selectivity, and outstanding stability when used in various electrocatalytic reactions. Meanwhile, due to their unique physical/chemical structure, SACs are uniquely advantageous in recognizing reaction sites. Combined with advanced characterization tools and DFT calculations, it is possible to gain a deeper understanding of the structure and properties of the SACs surface, the nature and state of the reactant molecules, and their interaction mechanisms. Therefore, due to the unique structure of SACs, the details and mechanisms of these processes can be accurately revealed, thus providing theoretical guidance for the design of more efficient electrocatalysts. In conclusion, an in-depth understanding of the electrocatalytic reaction mechanism can help develop more efficient electrochemical devices and technologies that can contribute to various fields, such as environmental protection, energy storage, and transportation. 7 Conclusion and outlook 7.1 Conclusion In conclusion, SACs originating from MOFs have the advantages of enzyme-like, heterogeneous, and homogeneous catalysts, low ligand environments, and atomic isolation. With these advantages, SACs have abundant active sites and excellent stability and thus have a promising application in electrocatalytic HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR. This review provides an overview of representative SACs originating from MOFs derived from the numerous synthetic SAC strategies. First of all, we summarize typical SACs originating from MOFs in recent years, analyzing and summarizing typical examples of each synthetic strategy to discuss their synthetic mechanisms. Then, in today’s rapidly changing technology, the characterization techniques of SACs are gradually improving. Among the many characterization tools, we discuss the typical and necessary ones. For example, AC-TEM, XAFS/XANES, in situ FTIR (Raman/XAFS), and theoretical calculations allow us to understand the local coordination environment, spatial distribution, and local electronic structure of the active centers of SACs [444]. In conclusion, this review outlines the multiple electrocatalytic uses of SACs (SACs originating from MOFs). In addition, SACs that can be applied to both the reducing and oxidizing ends of the process are analyzed in terms of adsorption of reactant molecules, activation and formation of intermediates, electron transfer and product formation, and desorption of final products from the SAC surface. Based on the information above, SACs exhibit excellent performance, stability, and selectivity in various electrochemical processes. Moreover, they significantly contribute to researchers’ comprehension of electrocatalytic reaction mechanisms and pathways. 7.2 Outlook Despite the excellent contributions of SACs in identifying active sites and reaction mechanisms, there are still some critical challenges for SACs to be solved by researchers to realize that SACs will shine in practical applications in the future. Therefore, more efforts in this area are needed to improve further the electrochemical performance of SACs originating from MOFs for their practical applications in the future. Several current challenges and future solutions are described below (Fig. 22 ). (1) Among the various synthesis methods, MOFs as an origin is the most suitable method for the preparation of SACs. However, this method mostly uses calcination and acid washing to prepare SACs, leading to high energy consumption, safety, and environmental concerns. Therefore, we must adopt environmentally friendly and sustainable synthetic methods to prepare SACs originating from MOFs, which can reduce production costs and minimize environmental impact. For example, green synthesis methods such as hydrothermal and microwave methods are used instead of the traditional high-temperature pyrolysis method. However, relatively few studies have been conducted in this area so far. Future research should be directed towards developing new environmentally friendly strategies for preparing SACs in large quantities from MOFs as a source. (2) Notably, considering the potential of SAs as reaction-active sites for electrocatalysts, it is necessary to pay more attention to the exposure of SAs in SACs. Therefore, combining SAs with MOFs or MOF derivatives with tunable pore sizes can show better mass transport and electron transfer capabilities, thus improving their electrochemical performance. (3) Preparing diatomic or triatomic electrocatalysts using atomic-level control technology will focus future researchers’ attention and development. Therefore, the coordination structure of SAs in SACs can be adjusted according to the desired applications and environments to obtain highly efficient and stable mono- or bifunctional (or even multifunctional) electrocatalysts. At the same time, precious metals can be used rationally, taking into account the scarcity of precious metals. (4) The development of various high-precision technical instruments brings about higher dimensional characterization, which allows more intuitive and accurate observation of the synthesis of reaction active sites and physical/chemical structural changes during the reaction process on a microscopic scale, such as atoms, such as AC-TEM, XAFS, and a variety of in situ characterization and other combinations of the use of various test instruments. It is worth noting that regionalization of test results due to test instruments, slow test efficiency, and deviation of test results from actual phenomena due to synergistic use of multiple in situ instruments are all problems that researchers need to face, and the expensive cost of the tests is also a pressing issue. (5) Due to the unique structure of SACs, its reaction sites are homogeneous. Combining advanced testing instruments with the SACs’ special structure helps study the electrocatalytic reaction process, leading to an in-depth understanding of the electrocatalytic reaction mechanism, which is essential for designing, improving, and creating better next-generation electrocatalysts. (6) In order to optimize the structural and electronic properties of SACs (especially those SACs originating from MOFs), researchers should be guided by a combination of experimental and theoretical studies, including molecular simulations and computational studies, to accelerate the progress of research on SACs and speed up their industrialization. Such modeling and theoretical simulations are commonly used to predict new SACs and explain their electrocatalytic reaction mechanisms through simulations. (7) In recent years, DFT has been widely applied to study the electrocatalytic reactions of SACs. The introduction of DFT can compensate for the lack of experimental conditions, both by guiding the experimental design through property predictions and by helping to characterize the experimental phenomena. DFT calculations will play an important role in the electrocatalytic study of SACs. By calculating the charge density difference, Gibbs free energy, and energy band structure of SAC, we can determine its degree of polarization, charge transport, reaction energy barriers, adsorption strength to reaction intermediates, etc., to predict its electrocatalytic performance. (8) DFT calculations are also an effective tool for investigating the mechanism of electrocatalytic reactions. It helps to elucidate the RDS of various electrocatalytic reactions, determine the reaction active sites of electrocatalysts, and obtain the reaction energy barriers for electrocatalytic reactions performed by different electrocatalysts. This information can provide guidance for optimizing the electrocatalytic activity and stability of the electrocatalysts. The combination of DFT calculations and experiments can systematically and deeply characterize the structure, electrocatalytic reaction mechanism, and performance enhancement mechanism of SACs and provide new ideas for the rational design and preparation of high-performance SACs. (9) However, existing theoretical calculations simulate much simpler systems than actual systems. For example, Gibbs free energy calculations can only simulate reaction energy barriers for specific reactions in specific regions of the electrocatalysts. Therefore, researchers need to develop a system that can demonstrate the actual process of changes in larger electrocatalyst regions and the electrocatalytic reaction’s transition state to simulate these changes in real time. This will drive innovation in electrocatalysts and accelerate the industrialization of SACs. (10) The SACs originating from MOFs are currently being investigated at the laboratory stage and are in the process of understanding the specific catalytic properties of single atoms from a fundamental research perspective and extending other SA catalytic systems. Successful application of SACs in chemical processes is not only expected to reduce costs and promote economic development but also has the potential to reduce production energy consumption and contribute to CO2 emission reduction. (11) Several essential chemical processes that are expected to realize the application of SACs in the future include (but are not limited to) alkane (oxidative) dehydrogenation, carbonylation, hydroformylation, olefin purification (selective hydrogenation), and so on. Therefore, SACs will be an important direction for future catalytic research, both in terms of theoretical understanding of the nature of catalytic reactions and in terms of potential applications in industry, and they may replace conventional catalysts in some specific areas. (12) Machine learning (ML): the impact of big data is becoming increasingly evident with the trend toward multidimensional, diverse, and complex information. Due to the complexity of the factors affecting the electrocatalytic reaction, there are many parameters involved in the study, and the relationship between the variables is very complicated. For example, selecting electrocatalyst materials, determining crystal surfaces, screening surface reaction sites, etc. Screening electrocatalytic materials by human power alone is a cumbersome task with unsatisfactory results. ML can effectively improve this situation, making the research more efficient and even exploring the regularities of the electrocatalyst properties independently of the electrocatalyst themselves. (13) ML methods can have a significant impact on various aspects of research. These methods can enhance research efficiency, improve prediction accuracy, facilitate the discovery of novel materials, shorten research and development cycles, and conserve resources. As a result, ML methods can help improve existing traditional methods or give rise to new methods and technologies. This is undoubtedly a novel approach to material screening. In the new energy materials field, the ML method will shine and even trigger a disruptive revolution, but there is still a long way to go before it reaches maturity. By explaining the various materials, concepts, and fields and analyzing them from multiple perspectives, SACs originating from MOFs will soon shine in various fields of chemistry. We hope the insights summarized and integrated into this review will facilitate research in this field and accelerate its development. Ed., 2019, 58, 11868–11873. Jizhou Jiang is currently a full Professor in School of Environmental Ecology and Biological Engineering, Wuhan Institute of Technology (WIT). He completed his PhD in the Huazhong University of Science & Technology (HUST) in 2015. This was followed by a period of postdoctoral research at National University of Singapore under the supervision of Prof Andrew T. S. Wee from 2015 to 2017. His current research focuses on the preparation of novel micro/nano-materials, 2D materials, carbon materials and their applications of photo/electro-catalysis. Hongjun Dong is an associate researcher at the Institute of Green Chemistry and Chemical Technology, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University, China. He received his BS and MS degrees in the College of Science, Yanbian University, in 2003 and 2006, respectively. He received his PhD degree in the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology in 2015. He worked as a postdoctoral research fellow in the group of Prof. Can Xue in Materials Science and Engineering at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore from 2015 to 2016. His research interests include the application of photocatalysis techniques in the degradation of pollutants, hydrogen generation from water splitting, fuel conversion of carbon dioxide, etc.

coredata.dc:description: ABSTRACT Significant environmental issues have emerged from the increasing usage of fossil fuels, stimulating extensive interest in improving efficient energy production and storage systems. Electrocatalysis, which plays a crucial role in clean energy conversion, could foster the advancement of future sustainable technologies. Electrocatalytic activity is greatly enhanced by single-atom catalysts (SACs) because of their distinctive physical and chemical frameworks. The coordination environment can influence the geometry and electronic structure of SACs, contributing to the escalation of the efficiency of electrocatalytic for meeting practical needs. Due to their numerous micropores, greater surface area, and adjustable organic ligands, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been shown to be an excellent approach to developing SACs. This review provides a complete summary of current instances involving the synthesis of SACs originating from MOFs. In addition, this review also addresses the impact of single-atoms (SAs) on electrocatalytic activity within the local coordination environment, including the spatial distribution, coordination structure, and local electronic structure. Besides, the density functional theory that provides theoretical support for the electrocatalytic reaction has summarized and analyzed the application of SACs in the electrocatalytic field.

coredata.dc:title: State-of-the-art advancements in single atom electrocatalysts originating from MOFs for electrochemical energy conversion
